She slowly ends up having to toss everything she understood about herself and her life out the window. But by that time, things have gone awry – it’s too late for her to run from the approaching danger.
Maggie MacCormack and the Witches’ Wheel is often times quite charming, while at other times nail-bitingly grim. It is a love letter to imagination, gripping adventure and Earth’s environment.

 
Supporting Literacy
This author supports literacy through access.
3% of Maggie MacCormack and the Witches’ Wheel gross sales, in perpetuity, will be donated to: www.childrensbookbank.com
 
Giving Back to the Environment and Local Community
Maggie MacCormack, though heavy on the magic, is based on a daunting reality: introducing toxins into the environment compromises or destroys entire ecosystems. And for that, there are no magic remedies.
7.5 % of Maggie MacCormack and the Witches’ Wheel gross sales will be donated as explained below. (Kaja is not affiliated with the beneficiaries.)
2.5% of Maggie's gross sales will be donated, in perpetuity, to https://www.sealegacy.org;
2.5% of Maggie's gross sales will be donated, in perpetuity, to https://onetreeplanted.org;   
2.5% of Maggie's gross sales will be donated to https://barriefoodbank.org/
So:
Of each $18.00 softcover sold $1.35 goes to the non-profits named above.
Of each $36.00 hardcover edition sold $2.70 goes to the non-profits named above.
If we sell 2,500 softcover and 500 hardcover editions: $4,725 goes directly to the non-profits named above. If we sell 5,000 softcover and 1,000 hardcover $9,450 goes directly to the non-profits named above.
The more books sold, the more money is donated.
 
Why Kaja Publishes Through His Own Imprint
Many of Kaja Blackley’s other projects have been represented by major agencies. However, the time between selling a manuscript and seeing it on the bookshelves can be as long as three to four years. Acquisition editors are liable to overlook quality material –– J.K. Rowling’s Harry Potter and The Philosopher Stone was rejected; Frank Herbert’s Dune was rejected; CS Lewis’ The Chronicles of Narnia was rejected; Kenneth Grahame’s The Wind and The Willows was rejected; William Golding’s Lord of the Flies was rejected; Melville’s Moby Dick was rejected; Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby was rejected; Dr. Seuss was rejected; Agatha Christie was rejected; heck, Beatrix Potter’s Peter Rabbit was rejected so many times Potter published it herself. (Peter Rabbit has now sold over 150 million copies in 35 languages). Kaja would rather put his trust in his prospective readership.

Size and Format
Maggie MacCormack and the Witches’ Wheel will be printed in softcover and hardcover.
The dimensions are 5.5” x 8.26”.
The cover will be full colour, with spot varnish and foil stamping. The interior pages will be printed in two colours, and will include several two-colour illustrations.
A full-colour tip-in will be a feature in both editions.
The softcover edition will have three-inch cover flaps.
The hardcover edition will include a slip case and full-colour end papers.
 
Goals
The initial print run will be 2,500 softcover and 500 hardcover editions. Kaja has invested $1,000 of his own money into this campaign and is seeking to raise another CAD$9,500 , for a goal of CAD$10,500.
If $14,000 is raised the print run will increase to 5,000 softcover, 1,000 hardcover.
The print run will not be finalized until the end of this campaign.
The more books bought. The more we can give to the environment.
 
Stretch Goals
$14,000 will unlock a set of three bookmarks for the $56 contribution category and higher.
$20,000 will unlock a six-colour, 23 ½” x 15 ¾” poster for the $56 contribution category and higher.
$27,000 will unlock a T-shirt for for the $56 contribution category and higher.
$50,000 will unlock an audio book of Maggie for the $56 category and higher, and send our team to the Frankfurt book fair, October 2018 to premiere Maggie MacCormack and the Witches’ Wheel  internationally.
 
Production Cycle
10 business days for pre-production: proofing the proofs
10 business days for printing and binding
15 business days for shipping from printer in China
10 business days to process and ship orders
15-20 business days for delivery, depending on geographical location
Estimated delivery date: July 26, 2018.
 
Shipping Information
Every care is taken to ensure that you receive the items you order intact and within production cycle estimates. All items are shipped “Tracked Package” from Canada. Every backer will receive their own tracking number by email on the day their perk has shipped. We do not control the shipping charges. Prices are estimates provided by Canada Post in advance of this campaign.
 

Risks and Remedies
In over 30 years of publishing, printing, distributing and shipping, Kaja has on many occasions supervised printing and shipping from Asia. At the risk of sounding a bit Monty Python-like, the boat carrying your order could sink en route to our port of delivery…but it’s highly unlikely. It is possible that some individual orders may be lost in transit.
We will address each instance of loss in transit expeditiously and on a case-by-case basis. If we determine that a shipment has indeed been lost in transit, we will replace your order once, at no additional cost to you.
The honest truth is that Maggie MacCormack and the Witches’ Wheel is ready to print and -- notwithstanding the risks mentioned above -- we do not anticipate any obstacles preventing us from delivering your book as laid out in our production cycle estimates.
We will provide regular updates keeping our supporters informed throughout this venture.
Sincere and humble thanks for your support.
 
 
The Maggie MacCormack Campaign Team

Storytime:

About the Author

  **For those who would rather watch the details of this campaign and the author, simply click on the Campaign Video**

            When I started performing professionally at the age of twelve, I never really knew where the journey would lead me. As a songwriter and recording artist, I was fortunate enough to have three top ten songs on the national charts, not to mention having the privilege of performing with top names in the Country music industry such as Loretta Lynn, Charlie Daniels and Pat Boone. 

            As my career diversified, I co-hosted Music City Today, a nationally syndicated television, and also hosted my own show called, Music and Entertainment Tonight. As an actor, I have been involved in an ever-growing list of television shows and films, which includes A Walk In The Woods, allowing me to share a bit of screen time with the Nick Nolte and Robert Redford.  

             Along the way, my passion for American History consumed my heart and mind, so I created a new genre in the industry that I dubbed “edutainment”. I combined my music and acting into a one-man show, traveling all over Tennessee to schools and events, which allowed me to bring characters like General George Washington and Colonel David "Davy" Crockett from the pages of history, into the open for all to enjoy. 

            My life seemed to be going smoothly, until my father’s health began to gradually deteriorate. By 2013, Lewy Body Dementia took over his very being and sense of self. I had always promised my parents I would take care of them when they grew old, so when duty came calling, I didn't hesitate to step up. By late 2013, medical facility visits became a constant. There was even one occasion where Mom was sick in one hospital, and Dad was in another. When I brought Dad home for hospice care, I became his full-time caretaker. 

            When he passed away on Christmas Eve of 2014, Mom became severely depressed, then her health began declining. She had many setbacks during 2015, then when she fell in January 2016, she broke her wrist, and the situation worsened. After her operation, the anesthesia triggered dementia, causing her behavior and mindset to become more erratic and less predictable. While she remained in a confused state a majority of the time, she refused to take her medication properly. She passed away suddenly in September 2016. 

            The time spent taking care of my parents was the most rewarding period of my life. They both wanted to avoid becoming permanent residents in a nursing home, and desired to die peacefully in their own beds at their home on the farm. I'm proud to say that they both got their wish. 

            During my time as a caretaker, I needed something to keep myself busy while sitting in the hospital, so I took out my laptop and began to do some writing. I never would have dreamed that this would be the path which God had been pushing me toward all along. 

            A friend gave me a book in 2011 titled, “Jack Hinson's One-Man War” by Tom C. McKenney. Shortly after finishing it, I was so inspired that I wrote a song called "The Ballad of Captain Jack". After recording it, Tom McKenney heard it for the first time in February of 2012. We became friends in no time, deciding to work jointly on the promotion of his book and my new song. It was during this period that he challenged me to write a movie script about Jack Hinson, so I couldn’t resist. As soon as he read my screenplay, Tom suggested I take the script and expand it into a full-length historical fiction novel. 

            After working on the project for over two years, I took a tally of what I had written and realized I had over a thousand pages. I readily made the call to turn the project into a four-book series. Utilizing Tom's biography on Captain Jack as my starting point, I did my own extensive research in twenty-six additional credible resources. Although my book is considered a work of historical fiction, many new details have emerged regarding Jack Hinson and the people he interacted with in his daily life.

            While speaking with Tom in July 2017, I presented him with one of my new findings. It was during this conversation he suggested I call Scott Campbell at River Road Press. Tom took it one step further, making the introductory call himself. Within a few hours, I was speaking with the book publisher on the phone and in December 2017, I drove to New Orleans to meet Mr. Campbell in person. After our visit, I finally had someone who was willing to publish my first book, In The Hills Of Tennessee: The Uncivil War. The book will be in hardcover format, with over sixty black and white illustrations, and historic photos from the 1860’s. Twenty graphic art pieces completed by myself are also included, as well as six illustrations by renowned artist Andy Thomas. 

            At present, the scheduled release of the book is set for October 2018. Although River Road Press will be paying for all of the expenses to print the books (as well as supplying them in stores), I still have expenses that I must take on myself. As per industry standard, I will receive a case of 24 books free, but the rest of the inventory I must purchase to have product to sell at my book signings. I will also have to incur the cost of reproducing the full color prints of my artwork, the national marketing campaign, and the travel expenses to my book signings/shows. 

            This is the part that I am absolutely thrilled about. I am turning to family, friends, fellow history lovers, and art connoisseurs to help me get this project off the ground. I have chosen the Indiegogo crowdfunding platform to make it possible for everyone to get involved with this groundbreaking series about Captain Jack Hinson, a man history has yet to forget.  

            I hope to see each of you soon as the book tour comes to your hometown! 

 

LEGAL DISCLAIMER: The items used therein, artwork and photographs, are copyrighted materials and are subject to litigation if they are stolen or duplicated. You must seek permission from the rights holder to use these items in any way shape or form for personal means or otherwise.

 

 

Why Should I Donate to This Campaign?

      The times we live in are undoubtedly frustrating and horrific. The thought police are on the rise. Political correctness and virtue signaling is all the rage. History is literally being attacked, and we should not allow for it to proceed any further! And all the while, the ones doing the berating are oblivious to the origin behind the events which actually transpired. 

Facts are being misconstrued and misrepresented.

The political climate is humid at best, and that is why this series is vital to this generation, and many more to come. History is being erased before us, and even though it's possible this series may not make a dent in the metaphorical barrel that is labeled "NO FACTS, NO HISTORY", this is a passionate effort to enlighten the minds of the misinformed, and provide those who are well-versed in the subject more information about the past, with hearty entertainment sprinkled in along the way.

Many vital steps need to be taken so we as a nation can make the corrections to history mainstream, as well as preserving the simplicity which magnifies the allure and beauty of the Civil War era. We believe donating to this campaign is not only one of said steps which could generate an open dialogue about the state of our country, but could furthermore spread awareness about the threat of history being eradicated from our lives.

The remembrance of our ancestors and all those who came before, and the great sacrifices they made so we could enjoy our liberties today, will all be in vain if we cannot find a way to stop this whirlwind of strife that has invaded our government, our schools, our churches, and even our homes.

 

 

New Information Found

There are also certain places and events which surround the Battle at Fort Donelson and Stewart County, TN, that have not been amended in an official capacity, but are spoken about in the series. It is our highest hope that we can present this new information to historical societies around the country so it can stand corrected!

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

     Funding received for this campaign will be going toward the nationwide book tour, set to kick off in October 2018, mere days proceeding the release of the first book in the Chronicles of Captain Jack Hinson series, In the Hills of Tennessee: The Uncivil War. It will also go toward the purchase of cases of books from the publisher, as well as money to use for the art prints.

The full budget is listed in the category below!

There have been tireless efforts to publish this series, and after a decade of hard work and dedication, Rick Revel finally wants to see his life's work come to fruition.

  • Being such a wide variation of art to choose from in the perks section, we assure you there's definitely something for every student of American History, Civil War enthusiast, or simply even a lover of graphic artwork!

 

The Budget

   As the project becomes a success, you will have bragging rights that you helped to get it all started! If you see the book mentioned in a nationally recognized magazine or online venues, we are willing to wager that your heart will swell with pride, knowing you were able to play a role in getting the ball rolling for this series!

 These are all approximate amounts estimated from Rick Revel's experience in the entertainment industry. No amount is set in stone and can be subject to change.

  • For every donation that fits within the perks guidelines, you will receive a full color print of my artwork. There are 15 different prints to choose from, so you can fill your home, office, or business with these historic graphic portraits! 
  • Purchasing 1,000 extra books, the cost will be $12,500.00
  • Purchasing 500 full color prints of artwork, the cost will be $12,500.00.
  • Advertising is a must, which will require placement in magazines and newspapers, and considering the times we live in, a large amount will go into ads for social media & internet sites. The minimum budget to get adequate coverage is $15,000.00.
  • There is also a tentative plan to produce a YouTube video trailer with actor portrayals, costing $5,000.00.
  • The travel expenses for the multi-city book tour will be approximately $5,000.00.
  • The total proposed budget is $50,000.00.

 

 

About the Book Series

   All Jack Hinson ever wanted was to be left alone, so that he and his family could live peacefully, but after his two sons were murdered by Union soldiers, all hell broke loose in the hills of Tennessee.    

To put this series into an unambiguous perspective, picture this: In The Hills Of Tennessee: The Uncivil War  has a Little House On The Prairie ambiance which is focused on the importance of familial devotion, but then when you mix in the seductive magnetism of Gone With The Wind, then top it off with the gunslingin’, horse-ridin', never-back-down attitude of The Outlaw Josey Wales? It is a near impossibility to not be elated reading this series, not to mention, being able to learn about American History in a satisfying way. These pieces of the past were buried for years and untold by historians and teachers alike, until now. 

 

 

Risks & Challenges

  • One of the largest risks involved in this project is not attaining the campaign goal. We are relying on you, the people, to propel this forward and spread the word about how important this series truly is in preserving the American spirit. Because once the budget is attained, we can go the rest of the way!
  • A possible challenge to overcome would be not having the ability to market the series enough for it to receive adequate coverage, which could heavily affect sales. We are going to put our ALL into pumping out the proper ads to audiences who want to see them.
  • Wrap your mind around this: We only need 1,000 people to donate $50 each in order to reach the proposed goal. In reality, that isn't a large number of people, but can be challenging for someone who has been out of the public arena for a good while. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute through monetary means, simply sharing this campaign to Facebook, Twitter, or email to get the word out will help dramatically!

You can also share the link to Rick's new fan page on Facebook!

See Rick Revel's personal website to learn more about him, his cause, and his life as an entertainer.

story:
Wizards in Space is at it again.

We accomplished a lot in 2017, and we’re looking ahead to make 2018 our biggest and best year yet.

Wizards in Space believes in paying artists for their work, and we believe in signal boosting authentic voices and experiences that connect us to our own morality, humanity, and the parts inside us that also really like pizza and the vastness of space.

This year, instead of individual campaigns for each issue, we’re taking lift off for 2018 all at once. We're using the model of a standard lit mag subscription service, which means a discounted amount if you donate to support BOTH issues (better for you and us).

Also included are the perks we couldn’t let go of, the ones that keep the sparkles in our eyes: Riley’s excellent hand-drawn space wizard doodles, and Olivia's meaningful and heartfelt pick-me-up envelopes.  

So what are we trying to do?

Wizards in Space Literary Magazine is a literary magazine of original creative works by writers spanning a wide array of backgrounds, identities, and lived experiences. Coming from a community rooted in pop culture and fandom, we aim to bring original works to fan spaces and beyond.

For many writers and artists, particularly those whose voices have historically been silenced, the bridge from content consumer to creator can be nearly impossible to cross. This magazine was born of the idea that all writers should have a space to showcase their work, especially in communities that already so actively celebrate stories. We want to continue our work to expand creative spaces to include writers of all levels and all backgrounds, and to give their work a constant, safe home.  

We put the magic of an open mic onto paper, and we want to fill these pages with your voices.

And who are we?

Many of you already know who we are and what Wizards in Space is all about. If that’s the case, stop reading and go donate! What are you waiting for? If you’re new to the WiS Crew, read on to find out more.

Olivia Dolphin is the creator and founder of Wizards in Space Literary Magazine. Currently, she works as a Proofreader and Video Content Coordinator for ALEX AND ANI on the Content Marketing team. She has a Master's from Emerson College in Publishing and Writing, was the Managing Editor of the Harry Potter Alliance's W.A.N.D. Magazine, and has been published in a variety of lit mags including East Coast Inc. and 48 Review. Olivia is an active spoken word poet, zine creator, and has organized readings at The Wizard Rock House Show Series at Malfoy Manor, LeakyCon, Nerdcon, and the Granger Leadership Academy.

Thræn, marginalized voices expert, is passionate about the power of stories to build empathy and catalyze change. They can usually be found staring at spreadsheets and maps or firmly stating their intention to be best friends with every dog they meet. They are in their final semester of a BA (Hons) in Youth and Community Work

Bailey Share-Aizic is a student, editor, and creative type on a mission to make the world better than she found it. Her poetry has been nominated for Pushcart and Sundress awards, and recent work can be found in Rogue Agent, Right Hand Pointing, and Calamus. Find her holed up in a library somewhere, probably reading Audre Lorde, coding frantically, or jamming out to Kesha.

Cameron Brown is an enthusiastic reader and compulsive Twitter scroller with an ever-growing array of podcasts, webcomics, and internet writers to obsess over. His to-read pile lies toppled in ruin, books rescued one at a time from the debris, yet somehow it only expands. Soon he will be lost in the scattered pages. Drums sound in the deep, or is that the toppling of hardcover tomes?

Riley Wackernagel, is an art student at Savannah School of Art and Design and is our incredibly talented illustrator and creative director. Riley is responsible for the spirit of Wizards in Space: fun, wacky, spacey, wizard-y, and, most importantly, welcoming. We want this project to feel like home, and Riley’s doing a fantastic job at that.

We're good at what we do. Here's our 2017 accomplishments to prove it: 

-Launched Issue 02!
-Sponsored GLA 2017 and hosted an unforgettable open mic
-Presented panels at NerdCon: Nerdfighteria, and hosted an incredible open mic
-Hosted 4 open mic nights at Malfoy Manor
-Encouraged and watched as people performed their work for the first time, and then the second time, and the third...
-Presented panels and hosted an INTERNATIONAL open mic at LeakyCon Dublin!

(Bring it on, 2018. I think we can top it.)

What difference can we make?

Hear from members of our community:

Daniel Lytle: "With each new, radically inclusive issue, Wizards in Space introduces me to crucial new voices and beautiful work that energizes me to get out and create, too. This spirit is carried forward by a supportive community where I’ve made some of my closest friends and was even inspired to share some of my own writing for the very first time at a WiS open mic. The Wizards in Space team aren’t just making a literary magazine; they’re driving a movement of participatory creation, and I can’t wait to see what this next chapter holds."

Haley Alexandra: "Olivia was looking for a place to put her writing & just decided to create her own place. Her passion is infectious."

Dustin Fowler: "Wizards in Space provided my friends and I the ability to take our talent and passion to a larger audience. The group surrounding this undertaking is full of supportive and inventive people who push one another to make the most of their creativity. Seeing the struggles and wins of friends is something that strengthens me daily. I love Wizards in Space. This project filled a void in the writing community and I can't remember what life was like before it existed."

Marigrace Angelo: "Wizards in Space is much more than a literary magazine. It’s a community and a support system. It’s a platform for the voiceless to speak out into the void. It’s smart, refreshing, and inspiring. It’s people celebrating each other while creating magic together, bright stars shining in a constellation."

Paige Breisacher: "Even before Wizards in Space opened up welcoming a physical space for me to share my poetry at an open mic, it opened up the possibility for me that I even had poetry inside me that needed sharing. The Wizards in Space community makes me feel like people care about what I have to say."

Brian Ross, Draco and the Malfoys: "It is amazing to see folks who have never spoken in front of a group before find the courage to share something intimate, of their own creation, and discover power there that doesn’t fade after it’s revealed. It’s a special ability our community has, and we are lucky Wizards In Space has provided this unique venue for creative writers so we can all share in their passion and their gifts."

What’s different this time?

We're fundraising our whole year at once so we can execute a timeline that is both jam-packed and organized. This is good news for writers who want to submit work, for our staff, and for all of you, who will get to experience what Wizards in Space can do when we're running on all cylinders.

By fundraising and setting up a subscription system, this allows us more time throughout the year to focus on marketing, finding niche communities that can benefit from our mission, and making sure that writers and storytellers know we’re here as a potential home for their work.

What We Need:

Production cost for one issue of Wizards in Space costs about $4,500. Because we pay everyone who gives their work to the mag (writers, illustrator, designer, and editorial staff), we believe in the power of paper books and want to keep printing, and we have a wide, international audience that receives our books, the cost to put out an issue is a little higher than other mags.

Funding needed:
Printing: $1,450
Shipping: $1,300
Editorial team: $700
Writers: $700
Submittable: $396
Miscellaneous costs: $150

 

Risks & Challenges

Fundraising for two issues at once is a risk. We know that our strategy this time around differs from our process in the past, but we hope that with two issues under our belt, we've earned your trust. We also recognize that this may place an undue financial burden on some of our supporters, which is the opposite of what we want. We've tried to design perks in a way that allows everyone to donate, regardless of how much money they have. We’ve also extended our timeline from 30 days to 45, to allow for more funding time.

Signal Boost

The best ways you can help Wizards in Space have lift off:

-Donate! (if you haven’t already)
-Tell your friends about us.
-Find your local writing groups and encourage them to donate.
-Share and remind your friends all the time to donate!

 

We have 45 days. Let’s do this.

We're using the model of a standard lit mag subscription service, which means a discounted amount if you donate to support BOTH issues (better for you and us).Also included are the perks we couldn’t let go of, the ones that keep the sparkles in our eyes: Riley’s excellent hand-drawn space wizard doodles, and Olivia's meaningful and heartfelt pick-me-up envelopes.  So what are we trying to do?Wizards in Space Literary Magazine is a literary magazine of original creative works by writers spanning a wide array of backgrounds, identities, and lived experiences. story:
Help Me Make My Dream Come True! 

¡Ayúdame A Que Haga Mi Sueño Realidad!  


When looking at this, you may think 'another campaign from someone wanting to publish a novel.' This is more than that : this is me fighting to live out a dream I've had ever since I was little.  I'm now 32 years old, and the dream is still there. Let me tell you why this campaign is different to the rest. 

I am not just anyone who decided to write a book just for something to do. Where others only deign to go, I desire to go. I am not the kind of person who has a dream and who does not persue it, or who gives up. 

In November 2013, I entered NaNoWriMo and wrote my debut novel called Spellbrooke. Writing is a challenge for anyone, more so for me as I was born with cerebral palsy and hydrocephalus and am registered legally blind. 

When I was born  on the 22nd December 1981 with my identical twin Natalie three months prematurely, I had lack of oxygen and was in the NICU for three months fighting for my life . I was on a ventilator for the first two weeks of my life , and so was my twin,  We both weighed 2lb 6oz.  I had a bilateral grade IV  (severe) brain bleed, jaundice, conjunctivitis and a whole host of other infections.  

Al mirar esto por la primera vez, puede que piensas 'otra campaña de alguien que busque publicar su novela' . Esto es más que eso: esta soy yo luchando para vivir un sueño que tenia desde que era niña . Ahora, tengo 32 años, y ese sueño que tenía sigue allí.   Dejad que te cuente por qué esta campaña es diferente al resto.  No solo soy una persona que decidió escribir un libro por tener algo que hacer.   Donde los demás no se atreven a ir  yo deseo ir . No soy el tipo de persona que tiene un sueño y no lo persigue, o una persona que se rinde. 

En noviembre de 2013, participé en NaNoWriMo y escribí mi primera novela titulada Spellbrooke.  Escribir es un reto para todos pero especialmente para  mí porque naci con paralisis cerebral e hidrocefalia y estoy registrada legalmente como  persona ciega . 

Cuando naci el dia 22 de diciembre   de 1981  junta a  mi hermana gemela Natalie Jane Hayward,  sufrí falta de oxigeno y pase tres meses en la UCI neonatal  luchando por mi vida.  Un ventilador me mantenia a mi y a mi gemela con vida. Yo pesaba 1 kilo 8 gramos . A causa de mi nacimiento  tenía una hemorragia cerebral de grado 4 (severa) en ambos lados de mi cabeza a la vez , ictericia, conjuncticitis y muchas mas infecciones. 

Cerebral Palsy is a neurological disability where lack of oxygen to the brain  during, after or at birth causes brain damage. There  are many types of Cerebral Palsy, and mine is Spastic Quadriplegia Cerebral Palsy which means my muscles are overly stiff and rigid and this makes movement difficult. The rigidness affects all my muscles. 

As my cerebral palsy affects my entire body, I require help in all daily tasks which include washing, dressing and eating and whenever I am out I have to be accompanied by somebody as I have very poor hand – eye coordination and my severe spatial awareness problems mean that I cannot judge distance speed or depth. I have problems with my balance, and have specialist seating in my wheelchair which has positioning wedges and pads inside, and the backrest has moulded sides to support my body. This is what keeps me upright, and even then it is a struggle to sit upright. 

I tire easily, but do what I can during the day, and have a happy and positive demenour. 

I also have deformities in my pelvis and hips and they are rotated at an angle so that my legs and feet turn  inwards. This also causes pain and discomfort on a daily basis. I have a lot of muscle spasms during the day which are very strong and worse when I am tired or when I experience strong emotions or changes in temperature.I cannot regulate my body temperature and have very bad circulation so my hands and feet are always cold and I feel the cold easily. . I have had countless operations and hospital checkups and am very lucky to be here today because I was given NO CHANCE  of survival by the doctors, and had to be revived on the third day of my life after suffering a heart attack, and was baptised in an emergency ceremony at hospital by the doctors and nurses in the NICU. My sister Natalie was given the same prognosis. 

¿Qué es la Parálisis Cerebral?

Aquí Puedes Averiguar Qué es la Parálisis Cerebral y Te Contaré con Gusto Para Que Llegas A Entender Más Sobre Mi Discapacidad Y  Podrás Ver Por Qué El Sueño Que Tengo De Ser Una Autora Y Publicar Un Libro No  Es Cosa Fácil Para Que Luchar . 

A Pesar de Eso No Me Rendiré. 

La parálisis cerebral es una  discapacidad neurológica en la cual la  falta de oxigeno al cerebro antes , durante o después del parto causa daño cerebral. 

Hay varios tipos de paralisis cerebral y el mio es  la Parálisis Cerebral Tetraplejia Espástica, que significa que mis músculos son demasiado tiesos y rígidos, y esto hace que el movimiento me sea difícil.   La rigidez afecta a todos mis músculos.  

Como la parálisis cerebral afecta a todos mis músculos,  requiero ayuda en todas las tareas de la vida diaria incluso vestirse, asearse y comer, y cuando salgo afuera, tengo que ser acompañada debido a mi  coordinación ojo-mano, que es muy mala. Mis problemas severas de conciencia y percepción del espacio significan que no puedo medir la distancia, la velocidad y la profundidad. Tengo problemas de equilibrio, y tengo un asiento y respaldo especial en mi silla de ruedas , que tiene cuñas de posicionamiento dentro del respaldo y el cojín, y el respaldo tiene soportes laterales incorporados.Aún así me dificulta estar sentada durante mucho tiempo.   

Me canso con facilidad y hago lo que puedo durante  el día . Tengo una actitiud positiva hacia la vida,  y soy una persona feliz. 

También tengo deformidades en mi pelvis y caderas, al igual que mis piernas y  mis pies. Esto también provoca dolor y malestar diarios  Tengo un montón de espasmos musculares durante el día que son muy fuertes , y son  peores  cuando estoy cansada o cuando yo experimento emociones fuertes o  hay cambios muy bruscos  en el tiempo . No puedo regular mi temperatura corporal y tengo  muy mala circulación. Mis  manos y mis pies siempre estan    fríos  y me siento el frío con facilidad. He tenido innumerables operaciones y  pruebas en el  hospital ,  y estoy muy orgullosa de estar aquí  hoy , porque  los medicos no me daban  NINGUNA POSIBILIDAD de sobrevivir y tuve que ser reanimada en el tercer día de mi vida después de sufrir un ataque al corazón, y fue bautizado en la ceremonia de emergencia en el hospital por los médicos y las enfermeras en la UCIN. Mi hermana Natalie  tenia el mismo pronóstico.

 

Hydrocephalus is a neurological disability in which, due to  brain injury (in my case, the severe bleeding inside my brain) the levels of cerebrospinal fluid, which protects the brain and spinal cord,  are so high they cause the brain  and skull to swell .  I was lucky in that I was operated on quickly when I was two weeks old . This was an extremely risky operation as I was so small and premature. The operation was to put a drainage system called a shunt inside my brain to drain off the excess fluid. The drainage system is a pressure valve attached to a  catheter (tube)  that goes into my abdomen. Just because I have this, it doesn't mean my hydrocephalus is cured or that it has disappeared, it hasn't. In fact, there is NO CURE  for either of my disabilities. 

My hydrocephalus is said to be controlled because of the shunt, but it is like a ticking timebomb because whenever I have a headache nausea or vomiting, it could mean that the shunt is fractured or blocked and I would have to be operated on immediately. If not, the consequences could be fatal.  I get frequent  headaches and pains in my head around the area where the shunt is , and due to all the operations the sensitivity in my head has changed, so a daily task like having my hair washed or  brushed is more like a time of discomfort than pleasure for me, as my head is very sensitive to touch

¿Que es la Hidrocefalia?  La Hidrocefalia Es  La Otra Discapacidad  Que  Tengo. Esta Sección  Explica  Más Sobre  La Hidrocefalia .  Esta Es Una Discapacidad Que  Las Personas  No Saben Que  Tengo Porque  No Es Visible 

La hidrocefalia es una  discapacidad de origen neurológica  en la ual, debido a una lesión cerebral (en mi caso, la severa hemorragia dentro de mi cerebro) los niveles de fluido cerebroespinal, que protegen el cerebro y la columna vertebral , son tan altos que causan el cerebro y el cráneo a hincharse. He tenido suerte en que fui intervenida rápidamente cuando sólo tenía dos semanas de vida. Fue una operación muy arriesgada porque yo era muy pequeña y prematura. La operación fue  para  poner un sistema de drenaje llamado una  válvula de derivación  dentro de mi cerebro para drenar el exceso de líquido cefaliraquideo    El sistema de drenaje es una válvula de presión conectada a un catéter (sonda) que se adentra en mi abdomen. Sólo porque tengo esto, no significa mi hidrocefalia este  curada o que haya desaparecido, no lo ha hecho. De hecho, NO hay cura para ninguna de mi discapacidades. 
Mi hidrocefalia se dice que esta controlado debido a la desviación, pero es como una bomba de relojería  porque  cada  vez que tengo  náuseas,  dolor de cabeza o vómitos, puede significar que la válvula de derivacion este      fracturada o bloqueada y que tendría que ser operada inmediatamente. Si no, las consecuencias podrían ser fatales. Tengo frecuentes dolores de cabeza y en mi cabeza alrededor del área donde está la desviación y debido a todas las operaciones, me  ha cambiado la sensibilidad en la cabeza, así que una tarea diaria como que alguien me lave o cepille  mi cabello es más como un momento de malestar que placer para mí, mi cabeza es muy sensible al tacto. 


My eyesight difficulties are nystagmus, which is a constant, uncontrolled side – to – side eye movement associated with cerebral palsy , squint in both eyes, tunnel vision and an eye condition called hemianopsia where my visual field is severely restricted because I have blindness in one half of both eyes, and so I'm working with the equivalent of one eye with very restricted eyesight doing the work of two which has always caused me a lot of difficulty focusing my eyes, eyestrain, very bad headaches and dizziness, even though I am sitting down.

As as a result of all of these eye conditions due to my cerebral palsy,  and hydrocephalus , am registered legally blind. I have relied on glasses my whole life but they do not correct my vision and I am only able to see a very small amount despite the highly specialist, strong lenses I have. I rely on an electric wheelchair to get around. The tightness of my muscles causes them to cramp easily and I have muscle spasms for which I have to take daily medication. These spasms are also very painful.

I have had my fair share of stares, insults and endured constant bullying during my school years.  People   have doubted and criticised   me,  and still do, but that has never stopped me, and never will . 

I am a person who's grown from not confident at all to believing in myself throughout the course of my life so far. After a difficult entry into the world I have always strived to fight for what I believed in, whether or not others thought I'd achieve it or not , and I am happy with what I have achieved up til now, but always look for new challenges, goals and dreams to persue. I am engaged to my fiancée , Luis Alfredo Pérez Soto and have been for the past eight years now.  Having someone by my side who loves me for who I am and  who believes  in me is another dream come true, which I'm so grateful I've achieved. 

¿Cuales Son Mis Dificultades Visuales?

  En Esta Sección  Aprenderás  Sobre  Las Dificultades  Visuales  Que Tengo. Debido  A Mis Discapacidades. Estoy Registrada Como Persona  Ciega. 

Por Favor, Comparte  Un Lazo  Blanco Para Las Personas  Ciegas Y Los Con Vista  Parcial. 

Las dificultades que tengo en la vista son  nistagmo, que es un movimiento  constante e incontrolable de  mis ojos de un lado a otro  y estos movimientos oculares estan  asociados con la parálisis cerebral. Tambien tengo estrabismo ambos   ojos, visión de túnel y una afección ocular llamada hemianopsia donde mi campo visual está severamente restringido porque tengo ceguera en la  mitad de ambos ojos y así estoy trabajando con el equivalente de un ojo con una vista muy restringida haciendo el trabajo de los dos que  siempre me causó mucha dificultad para enfocar los ojos, ademas de vista cansada, muy fuertes dolores de cabeza y mareos, aun cuando estoy sentada. 


Como consecuencia de todas estas condiciones de la vista  debido a mi parálisis cerebral y la hidrocefalia, estoy registrada como una persona ciega. Toda mi vida he llevado gafas pero no corrigen mi visión y sólo soy capaz de ver una cantidad muy pequeña a pesar de las lentes fuertes que tengo. Dependo de una silla de ruedas eléctrica para desplazarme. La tirantez de mis músculos facilmente provoca  calambres,   y tengo espasmos musculares para los que tengo que tomar medicación diaria. Estos espasmos son también muy dolorosos.

A lo largo de los años que estaba en la escuela y el Instituto,  experimente bastantes miradas, insultos y acoso constante. Las personas  dudadaron de mi  y me criticaron, y todavía lo hacen, pero eso nunca me ha hecho rendirme en la vida ,  y nunca lo hará.

Soy una persona que , con el paso de los años, ha  mudurado, y mi actitud ha cambiado. He ido desde aun persona que no tenia confianza en si misma  a creer en mí misma durante el transcurso de mi vida hasta ahora. Después de una entrada difícil en el mundo , siempre me he esforzado por luchar por lo que yo creía,  y no  me afecto si otros pensaron podría lograr las cosas o no, y estoy contenta con lo que he logrado hasta hasta ahora, pero siempre busco nuevos retos, metas y sueños que perseguir.  Estoy  comprometida con   Luis Alfredo Pérez Soto,  y hemos estado juntos  durante los últimos ocho años ahora. Tener a alguien a mi lado que me ama  por quién  soy y que cree en mí es otro sueño hecho realidad, que estoy tan agradecida de  haber logrado.

 Despite my complex and severe disabilities , I have achieved  more than anybody thought I would in life.

I have no hearing problem (in fact , my hearing has been made better because of my lack of eyesight) I am able to talk, I can in fact , speak fluent Spanish.

 I have a university degree in human geography from the University of Reading (UK) which I gained in 2004. I did not get that single-handedly- I was constantly helped at university by carers and support workers,  and had to have someone writing for me in my classes as I couldn't keep up. I passed all my exams,  with extra time , enlarged exam papers so I could see them, and very frequent rest breaks.

My education was a mixture  of special education and mainstream school, but mainstream school with a full-time special needs assistant by my side at all times.

Mis Retos Y Logros En La Vida 

A pesar de mis discapacidades  graves y complejas, he logrado más de lo que nadie creía que lo haría en la vida.

No tengo ningún problema de audición (de hecho, la audiencia se hizo mejor por mi falta de visión) soy capaz de hablar, de hecho, puedo hablar español con fluidez.

Tengo una licenciatura en geografía humana de la Universidad de Reading (Reino Unido) que gané en 2004. No  lo consiguí por  yo sola  - constantemente fui ayudada en la Universidad por  cuidadores y trabajadores y tuve que  tener alguien escribiendo para mí en mis clases como  yo no podía . Aprobé todos mis  exámenes, y tenia tiempo extra para completarlos y mis profesores y cuidadora agrandaron los papeles y la letra de los  exámenes para que yo podía  verlos,mejor,    y tenia tiempos de descanso muy frecuentes. 

Mi educación fue una mezcla de educación especial y escuela ordinaria, pero la escuela ordinaria con un asistente para gente con  necesidades especiales a tiempo completo  a mi lado en todo momento.

 My Disability Awareness Work

In 2012, inspired  by the disability awareness movement and the need to tell my story, I started doing disability awareness work using  Facebook, and have created a page called Katherine Hayward my life with cerebral palsy. Around the same time I also started making videos on YouTube  (www.youtube.com/user/cpchick81 ) about my life, and they can be found in the links in the Gallery section of  this page. 

I do not know much about the very short life (nine days from birth ) of my identical twin sister, but I have a page dedicated to her on Facebook and that link is also on this page.

As part of my disabilities, I   cannot type and so use a speech recognition programme to use the computer.  The  National Novel Writing Month (NaNoWriMo) challenge was to write a 50,000 word novel in a month and I DID   on the 18th of November  2013 with time to spare until the end of the month. Writing my book was a real learning curve ! - I'm glad I was able to do it before my 31 st birthday as that was a great gift for me! 

Mi Trabajo De Concienciación  De La Discapacidad.

En 2012, inspirada en el movimiento de conciencia de personas con discapacidad y la necesidad de contar mi historia, comencé a hacer trabajo de conciencia  de la discapacidad usando Facebook,  y he creado una página llamada Katherine Hayward mi vida con parálisis cerebral. En la misma época también empecé a hacer videos en YouTube (www.youtube.com/ usuario/cpchick81) de mi vida, y se encuentran en los enlaces en la sección Galería de esta página.

No sé mucho acerca de la vida muy corta (nueve días desde el nacimiento) de mi hermana gemela idéntica, pero tengo una página dedicada a ella en Facebook y ese vínculo  también se encuentra en esta página de campaña. 

Como parte de mi discapacidad, no puedo escribir, así que uso un programa de reconocimiento de voz para usar la computadora. El reto del mes Nacional de escritura de novela (NaNoWriMo) era escribir una novela de 50.000 palabras en un mes y LO HICE  el dia   18 de noviembre de 2013 con tiempo de sobra hasta el final del mes. ¡Escribir mi libro era una curva de aprendizaje real! -¡Me alegro de que yo era capaz de hacerlo antes de mi  31 cumpleaños, ya que  fue un gran regalo para mí!

Spellbrooke  An Excerpt 
This excerpt is from my debut novel, Spellbrooke. 



CHAPTER ONE

It was the last day of school before the summer holiday, and Casey’s mother Carrie was getting her ready for school. Casey, age nine, attended special school in Meadowtown, Oxfordshire, where the family decided to live after having lived in London.  Casey and her younger brother, Nick, had to move school and make new friends, and had experienced many changes  in their short lives. The family,  who used to live in a ground floor apartment in a modern apartment block in London, got fed up of the city,  and decided to move to a more rural location.
Carrie Ford, a thin woman with straight brown hair down to her shoulders and pale  blue eyes, looked  through her daughter’s drawers.
‘It’s a special day today Casey,’ she said.
‘What do you want to wear then?’
Casey, who looked identical to her mother, but who wore glasses, looked up at her mother and said.
 ‘My purple dress’ - purple was her favourite colour - ‘and my white sandals’.
As the day was warm, the purple dress and white sandals were a great choice. The sandals were special ones that supported Casey’s feet well.  Casey needed to wear special sandals and shoes, as her hips were dislocated and her feet turned in due to the cerebral palsy she was born with.  She loved wearing pretty clothes, as any little girl does, and her bedroom was  full of pretty things.  It was painted a lilac colour, and had stencils of horses on the walls. Casey’s mum lifted her daughter into her electric wheelchair using the electric hoist, an electric lifter which had a soft harness instead of a seat  attached to it. It was on rails that were built into the ceiling in Casey’s bedroom and her bathroom, as it was the easiest, and safest, way of moving Casey from one place to another without her parents having to lift her as she could not stand up or walk because of her disability, When she was ready they went to have breakfast with the rest of the family before the school bus arrived.
 The sun shone into the kitchen, and they saw that Casey’s father John, and her brother,  Nick, were already sitting at the table.
‘Good morning Carrie, good morning Casey’ said John, kissing them both. 
John was a tall, thin  man with wavy brown hair and blue eyes. He was reading the Business section of the newspaper as usual, as he worked in nearby Linton as an architect, and needed to keep up with what was going on in his type of work. 
‘Hi Mum, Hi Casey’ said Nick.
‘Good morning Nick, darling’ said Carrie, as she kissed her son.
‘Hi Nick’ said Casey, and they began eating their breakfast.
Carrie only had time for a quick breakfast herself, but also found time to help her daughter with eating meals.  Casey’s coordination wasn’t good, and this made eating difficult for her. Casey had to take medication with her meals. Her medication were tablets called Baclofen, which helped relax her muscles, and Carrie had been told by Casey’s doctor and at the chemist that they were best taken with a milky drink, as the milk would protect Casey’s stomach. That was alright, as Casey loved drinks such as hot chocolate for breakfast. The occupational therapist, a lady who was in charge of helping Casey have equipment that helped her do things better, even if it was with help,  had assessed Casey and suggested a cup with a lid and a hole for a straw, so she could drink more easily, and that cup was on the table now.
 Carrie looked at her watch and turned to her husband.
‘Help Casey finish off breakfast please darling, I don’t want to be  late, not on the last day.’
Casey’s mum was a teacher at Casey’s school, Greenacres Special School, and since her daughter was born nine years ago, she hadn’t left her side.
‘I will’ he said,  and took the spoon from his wife’s hand.
Both Casey and her brother were eating Coco Pops, and her dad was eating Shredded Wheat. The kettle was starting to boil, and he asked his children what they wanted to drink.  They both had orange juice, and he served himself some tea in his trademark mug with a picture of a house on. 
He was an architect at the big company,  Smiths, which specialised in architecture and home decor. Instead of buying a house that was already built, he had bought land and got his colleagues to build their house from scratch, based on plans he had drawn. 
This was always a dream of his, to build his own home for his family. It was much better for Casey and Nick than the London apartment they’d lived in, which, although spacious and big enough for them, it wasn’t to be their home forever, as they wanted to have a proper family home with even more space and a bigger garden.
This house had it all.  It was a large, detached house built, like many older buildings in Oxford and Oxfordshire, with Cotswold stone. The sand-coloured bricks were more traditional and looked better in this area than red bricks, he thought, and he and his colleagues had planned the house very carefully, as he wanted his family to have the house they deserved, and he had managed to give them just that.
He gave himself a mental pat on the back as he sipped his tea, and helped his daughter finish her cereal. They ate some muffins, and then it was time for his seven -year-old son, Nick, to brush his teeth and be off to school.
‘Bye Nick’ said Carrie, John and Casey as Nick got up from the table to go and get his schoolbag.
 ‘Bye Dad’ answered Nick. ‘Bye Mum’ ‘Bye Casey.’
A few minutes later, they heard the front door close and he was gone.  Nick walked to his friend Tom’s house and they went to school together from there.
John always waited with Casey for the school minibus, which came to the house to collect her.  It was still 8; 30 AM.  It usually arrived at around 9 AM. .
 He took her to her own  bathroom, a large wet - room with an adapted toilet, which had a higher seat than a usual toilet, and a bar on the wall on either side of it for Casey´s safety. There was also an open shower area, and a bathtub with a bath lift. The bathroom was right next to her bedroom.  Next, he found her schoolbag, a rucksack (which was also purple).
By the time that was done, they heard a ring on the door bell. John opened the door and saw Sophie, one of the school’s care workers. Sophie had black hair almost to her waist and was Casey’s helper on the bus.
Sophie took Casey’s rucksack from John with a ‘thanks John’ and put Casey’s wheelchair on manual to be able to push it down the shallow slope from the front door.
The green minibus had been paid for by the local Council, and had an electric lift at the back for wheelchairs.  
The driver, Bill, came round to the back of the bus and  pressed the round red button on the side of the lift to make it reach the ground. He was a kind man in his fifties, with brown hair and glasses, who used to be an ambulance driver. 
As the lift whirred to the ground, he asked Casey and Sophie, 
‘Ready for the last day of school?’
 ‘Yes’, they both said. Sophie stepped onto the tail lift, which was big enough for two people, and held onto the side of Casey’s wheelchair for balance. It wasn’t long until the tail lift reached the level with the opening of the back of the minibus, and they were both safely inside. The minibus was spacious so as to be able to fit people in electric wheelchairs in, and Sophie helped Bill secure Casey’s  wheelchair to the floor of the minibus with hooks and straps after they had put her seat belt on, as every carer and mini bus driver was fully trained beforehand to take extra special care when making the children safe to travel in their wheelchairs. 
Not all of the children were in wheelchairs, but those who were were secured like this. After one last, gentle tug to make sure that the wheelchair was safe, Sophie herself sat in the seat next to Casey’s wheelchair and fastened her seat belt. Bill returned to the front of the bus. Sophie put her hand in Casey’s, as she knew that Casey got a bit nervous when travelling, even on the short fifteen minute journey from the Ford house to Greenacres Special School, as she didn’t like the  movement of the bus as it made her feel dizzy despite the way her wheelchair was tied down. Casey’s balance was affected by her cerebral palsy, and she had a harness to secure her into the wheelchair which she wore all the time, not just when travelling.
Casey looked around: the bus was almost full by the time it got to her house, and she spotted her best friend, Rachel. 
‘Hi, Rachel!’ she said,
‘Hi Casey’ replied Rachel,
Rachel Brown was the same age as Casey, and had long blonde hair and blue eyes. She was wearing a red jacket and jeans. She  sat in a manual wheelchair and also had cerebral palsy. Casey and Rachel had known each other for years, and their mums were best friends. They chatted excitedly about what they were going to do at school that day,
Casey’s favourite thing to do at school was read, and Rachel’s was, too. They were both top of the class in reading, and they had learnt to read quickly. Today was the end of term Book Fair, and they were both looking forward to having a new book to read for the holidays.
Just then, the bus pulled up to the school gates and Bill parked it in the reserved parking space. He pushed the button to open the doors at the back of the bus,  and put the lift down, so that the children and the carers could get off the bus. Everybody crossed the car park and went through the automatic doors into the building.
The fist person Casey and Rachel saw, unfortunately, was Angela, a thin girl with blonde curly hair, who was with her dark–haired friend, Kelly, and was a real bully.  Angela turned her wheelchair towards them, and said ‘so, who’s here today then? Maybe you’ll both finally learn something seeing as it’s the last day!’
Sophie said ‘Angela, you’d better get to class too, don’t you think?’
 ‘Go away, Angela’, Casey and Rachel said. They hoped she wouldn’t bother them for the rest of the day.
Greenacres Special School was a modern and spacious building, and was built only five years ago. It was a long, red brick building all on one level, and had ramps coming out of various doors. For Carrie and John Ford, it seemed the best choice for their daughter when they were choosing which school she’d go to, as since being built it had been awarded  ‘excellent’ in all of its OFSTED reports. They wanted Casey to get the best support possible in her classes.
The school was named after the huge area of land it was built on, and had its own outdoor swimming pool, as well as indoor hydrotherapy pool, rooms for physical and occupational therapy, and a sensory room. All the rooms had electric doors, and were big enough for a whole class of children in wheelchairs.
The teachers had hung the children’s’ paintings, artwork and stories on the walls, which were painted bright colours. There was the reading area in one corner, which had shelves full of books, and looked like  a mini library, and all the desks were large enough for any type of wheelchair to fit underneath, and could be changed  in both height and angle. Casey’s and Rachel’s desks were side-by-side.
All the children came into the class. In total, there were fifteen students in Casey’s class, and there were four assistants. Some of the children had their own personal assistants, like Casey did. Their teacher, Miss Honeysuckle, was twenty five years old, but despite that had lots of experience working with children with disabilities.  She sat at her desk and filled out the register for the day. Everybody was in the class today. She welcomed them and began the class.
The day consisted of using the sensory room, music, some reading and then it was lunchtime. Diane, a tall woman with short red hair who was Casey’s classroom assistant, accompanied her to the canteen, which was a large room with the same tables as the classrooms.
She got Casey’s  square purple lunchbox out of her rucksack, then opened the door and said ‘it’s a lovely day’.
When they saw the sunshine, Casey asked
 ‘Can we eat outside? I want to eat outside!’
‘Yes, me too’ said Rachel.
‘All right  girls, let’s go outside!’ said Diane, and opened the door wider to help Casey through.  Rachel followed. They went down the ramp and then found a large paved area by some trees. It was not very busy, so Casey, Diane, Rachel and Rachel’s assistant Jackie had their lunch there.  Then, suddenly, Angela appeared again, and ran her wheelchair into Rachel’s.
 ‘Be careful’, warned Diane, and Jackie.
‘I can see the stupid girls are back’, said Amanda, ‘I hope you learn something on your last day’.
 ‘Ignore her’, said the carers. When they had finished, they went back into the school building and back into class. 
Miss Honeysuckle told them that the Book Fair had just arrived, and that they would go and have a look at the books.  Casey and Rachel had beaming smiles on their faces when they heard this, and wanted to be the first in line to go. A few minutes later, the entire class was making its way into the school hall, where the Book Fair was held. A lot of the books were aimed at children with disabilities, for example, there were Braille books and large print books as well as books that could be used with e book readers. There were also some books for adults. Casey bought The Lion the Witch and the Wardrobe by CS Lewis, and Rachel bought a book of fairy stories. Whilst at the Book Fair, Casey even saw her mum, who taught people younger than Casey and Rachel. Miss Honeysuckle was busy looking at books for her class when she saw Casey’s mum, Carrie. 
‘Carrie’ she called, ‘over here.’ 
Carrie Ford walked over to where she was standing. Ella Honeysuckle said quietly, so as not to be overheard by the children ‘come to my classroom later, I have a surprise up my sleeve for the children - in fact, it’s a kind of end-of-term party’. 
‘Very interesting’ said Carrie. ‘I’ll be there in ten minutes.
’When the Book Fair ended, she felt excitement for the children.
 She led her own class back to their classroom. As her class of seven-year-olds put their books and rucksacks away with the help of their assistants, she told them that they were going to see Miss Honeysuckle’s class and off they went. 
As they reached her classroom door, Carrie knocked on it,  and was greeted by the sight of tables with food and drink on and the classroom was decorated with streamers in different bright colours, blue, pink, green and yellow.  There was even a banner with ‘HAPPY SUMMER HOLIDAYS!’ written on it, which Miss Honeysuckle herself had made.  The children had a great  time at the party, and then it was time to go home.   Miss Honeysuckle stopped the party at half past two, half an hour earlier than the school day usually ended, and said ‘and now, children, it’s time for the summer holidays!’
The children who had Personal Assistants were helped to get ready by them, whilst the other class assistants helped clear the tables from the party and leave the classroom tidier than it was.  The children were smiling and happy. They were all really excited to have time off school for the summer.  Miss Honeysuckle cleared the rest of the food away. Because Casey’s mother was a teacher and worked at the school, she would be allowed to take some of the food home, but she didn’t know it yet. 
Miss Honeysuckle took Casey’s mother and a classroom Assistant of hers called  Trisha, a black- haired twenty-year-old, and whispered ‘help me bring all this food and drink back to the Staffroom’, waving her hand towards  the leftover food and drinks. Between them, they did.
The Staffroom was at the opposite end of the building. They opened the red door  and some of the other teachers looked at them, wondering why they had the food and drink in their hands. They asked what they did to celebrate the end of term. When Ella and Carrie told them about the party, many teachers thought it was a good idea, and secretly promised themselves they’d be more imaginative next time. 
Miss Honeysuckle and Carrie put the food on the table. ‘Help yourselves’, said Trisha. There were smiles and low giggles as some teachers did just that, some snacking on what was left of the bags of crisps, cakes, party sausages, sausage rolls and caffeine-free soft drinks. 
 Georgina, a teacher who’d just arrived from, Boston, suggested sharing the food out amongst them.  All the teachers agreed this was a good idea, as many of the teachers had children themselves, and so the food would get eaten and not be wasted, Maggie, an Occupational Therapist, found some carrier bags in a nearby storage cupboard, and all the teachers started sharing the leftovers between them. There were two male teachers at the school: Ian Wainwright and David Smith. They were both very tall, with black hair and blue eyes.  David was eating a sausage roll and chatting to Ian.
‘It’s great we have some time off work now’ he said. 
‘Yes it really is’ answered Ian.
The door opened just at that moment, and Emily Pryor, the Headmistress walked in. Emily had long, curly red hair and brown eyes. She was petite, thin and very bubbly. All the teachers at Greenacres Special School agreed she was the best headmistress they’d had so far, and the school had flourished in the four years she’d been in command.  In a way, it was truly ‘her’ school.
‘Having fun?’  she asked them.  
All the teachers laughed. She remembered then that she had one last surprise for the term: she went to her locker, opened it, and took out a  bag of hand-painted  wooden photo frames. She had a real talent for art and crafts, and had made one for each teacher. They were individually decorated to reflect the personality of each member of her staff. She passed them round. Each was wrapped in tissue paper the same colour as the frame inside it.
Carrie opened the pale yellow tissue paper surrounding hers. The frame   had yellow sunflowers on it and, in curly painted letters, it said ‘sunny’
‘Aww thanks so much’ she said.
 Then, she found a Tupperware container in the small kitchen area of the Staffroom, and put some sausage rolls, inside before she closed the bright red lid. She also took some crisps, six cans of Lemon Fanta and Sprite and a bottle of caffeine-free-Coke.
She looked at her Dolce and Gabbana watch, which John had given her last Christmas, and said ‘right, I’d better go and get Casey.’
The teachers said their goodbyes, and she left the Staffroom.
When she got back to the classroom, Casey was ready and waiting in her summer coat and Diane was by her side.
 Diane gave her a hug, and said. ‘I’ll accompany you outside.’
 She did. The school minibus was there, Bill was waiting.
Suddenly, Carrie said ‘Bill, Casey’s coming with me.’ 
Casey said ‘why aren’t I going on the bus, Mum?’
Carrie explained  ‘I have the van with me’.
 She’d gone home in her lunch hour, left her car, and driven back to the school with the family’s adapted van.
Casey’s face broke into a grin. ‘Thanks, Mum’ she said.
The van was a great help for getting Casey around. It was a silver Fiat van which the family had bought years ago. Carrie opened the passenger door and put her black handbag on the seat,  and then opened the sliding door to put the carrier bags on one of the seats so she had her hands free to help her daughter. She pulled the ramp down, pulling the straps tight on each side of the ramp to create a safety barrier so it would be safer when they went up the ramp.

Help Me Make My Dream Come True! ¡Ayúdame A Que Haga Mi Sueño Realidad!  When looking at this, you may think 'another campaign from someone wanting to publish a novel.' This is more than that : this is me fighting to live out a dream I've had ever since I was little.  I'm now 32 years old, and the dream is still there. Let me tell you why this campaign is different to the rest. I am not just anyone who decided to write a book just for something to do. Where others only deign to go, I desire to go. I am not the kind of person who has a dream and who does not persue it, or who gives up. In November 2013, I entered NaNoWriMo and wrote my debut novel called Spellbrooke. Writing is a challenge for anyone, more so for me as I was born with cerebral palsy and hydrocephalus and am registered legally blind. When I was born  on the 22nd December 1981 with my identical twin Natalie three months prematurely, I had lack of oxygen and was in the NICU for three months fighting for my life . I was on a ventilator for the first two weeks of my life , and so was my twin,  We both weighed 2lb 6oz.  I had a bilateral grade IV  (severe) brain bleed, jaundice, conjunctivitis and a whole host of other infections.  Al mirar esto por la primera vez, puede que piensas 'otra campaña de alguien que busque publicar su novela' . Esto es más que eso: esta soy yo luchando para vivir un sueño que tenia desde que era niña . Ahora, tengo 32 años, y ese sueño que tenía sigue allí.   Dejad que te cuente por qué esta campaña es diferente al resto.  No solo soy una persona que decidió escribir un libro por tener algo que hacer.   Donde los demás no se atreven a ir  yo deseo ir . No soy el tipo de persona que tiene un sueño y no lo persigue, o una persona que se rinde. En noviembre de 2013, participé en NaNoWriMo y escribí mi primera novela titulada Spellbrooke.  Escribir es un reto para todos pero especialmente para  mí porque naci con paralisis cerebral e hidrocefalia y estoy registrada legalmente como  persona ciega . Cuando naci el dia 22 de diciembre   de 1981  junta a  mi hermana gemela Natalie Jane Hayward,  sufrí falta de oxigeno y pase tres meses en la UCI neonatal  luchando por mi vida.  Un ventilador me mantenia a mi y a mi gemela con vida. Yo pesaba 1 kilo 8 gramos . A causa de mi nacimiento  tenía una hemorragia cerebral de grado 4 (severa) en ambos lados de mi cabeza a la vez , ictericia, conjuncticitis y muchas mas infecciones. Cerebral Palsy is a neurological disability where lack of oxygen to the brain  during, after or at birth causes brain damage. There  are many types of Cerebral Palsy, and mine is Spastic Quadriplegia Cerebral Palsy which means my muscles are overly stiff and rigid and this makes movement difficult. The rigidness affects all my muscles. As my cerebral palsy affects my entire body, I require help in all daily tasks which include washing, dressing and eating and whenever I am out I have to be accompanied by somebody as I have very poor hand – eye coordination and my severe spatial awareness problems mean that I cannot judge distance speed or depth. I have problems with my balance, and have specialist seating in my wheelchair which has positioning wedges and pads inside, and the backrest has moulded sides to support my body. This is what keeps me upright, and even then it is a struggle to sit upright. I tire easily, but do what I can during the day, and have a happy and positive demenour. I also have deformities in my pelvis and hips and they are rotated at an angle so that my legs and feet turn  inwards. This also causes pain and discomfort on a daily basis. I have a lot of muscle spasms during the day which are very strong and worse when I am tired or when I experience strong emotions or changes in temperature.I cannot regulate my body temperature and have very bad circulation so my hands and feet are always cold and I feel the cold easily. . I have had countless operations and hospital checkups and am very lucky to be here today because I was given NO CHANCE  of survival by the doctors, and had to be revived on the third day of my life after suffering a heart attack, and was baptised in an emergency ceremony at hospital by the doctors and nurses in the NICU. My sister Natalie was given the same prognosis. ¿Qué es la Parálisis Cerebral?Aquí Puedes Averiguar Qué es la Parálisis Cerebral y Te Contaré con Gusto Para Que Llegas A Entender Más Sobre Mi Discapacidad Y  Podrás Ver Por Qué El Sueño Que Tengo De Ser Una Autora Y Publicar Un Libro No  Es Cosa Fácil Para Que Luchar . A Pesar de Eso No Me Rendiré. La parálisis cerebral es una  discapacidad neurológica en la cual la  falta de oxigeno al cerebro antes , durante o después del parto causa daño cerebral. Hay varios tipos de paralisis cerebral y el mio es  la Parálisis Cerebral Tetraplejia Espástica, que significa que mis músculos son demasiado tiesos y rígidos, y esto hace que el movimiento me sea difícil.   La rigidez afecta a todos mis músculos.  Como la parálisis cerebral afecta a todos mis músculos,  requiero ayuda en todas las tareas de la vida diaria incluso vestirse, asearse y comer, y cuando salgo afuera, tengo que ser acompañada debido a mi  coordinación ojo-mano, que es muy mala. Mis problemas severas de conciencia y percepción del espacio significan que no puedo medir la distancia, la velocidad y la profundidad. Tengo problemas de equilibrio, y tengo un asiento y respaldo especial en mi silla de ruedas , que tiene cuñas de posicionamiento dentro del respaldo y el cojín, y el respaldo tiene soportes laterales incorporados.Aún así me dificulta estar sentada durante mucho tiempo.   Me canso con facilidad y hago lo que puedo durante  el día . Tengo una actitiud positiva hacia la vida,  y soy una persona feliz. También tengo deformidades en mi pelvis y caderas, al igual que mis piernas y  mis pies. Esto también provoca dolor y malestar diarios  Tengo un montón de espasmos musculares durante el día que son muy fuertes , y son  peores  cuando estoy cansada o cuando yo experimento emociones fuertes o  hay cambios muy bruscos  en el tiempo . No puedo regular mi temperatura corporal y tengo  muy mala circulación. Mis  manos y mis pies siempre estan    fríos  y me siento el frío con facilidad. He tenido innumerables operaciones y  pruebas en el  hospital ,  y estoy muy orgullosa de estar aquí  hoy , porque  los medicos no me daban  NINGUNA POSIBILIDAD de sobrevivir y tuve que ser reanimada en el tercer día de mi vida después de sufrir un ataque al corazón, y fue bautizado en la ceremonia de emergencia en el hospital por los médicos y las enfermeras en la UCIN. Mi hermana Natalie  tenia el mismo pronóstico. Hydrocephalus is a neurological disability in which, due to  brain injury (in my case, the severe bleeding inside my brain) the levels of cerebrospinal fluid, which protects the brain and spinal cord,  are so high they cause the brain  and skull to swell .  I was lucky in that I was operated on quickly when I was two weeks old . This was an extremely risky operation as I was so small and premature. The operation was to put a drainage system called a shunt inside my brain to drain off the excess fluid. The drainage system is a pressure valve attached to a  catheter (tube)  that goes into my abdomen. Just because I have this, it doesn't mean my hydrocephalus is cured or that it has disappeared, it hasn't. In fact, there is NO CURE  for either of my disabilities. My hydrocephalus is said to be controlled because of the shunt, but it is like a ticking timebomb because whenever I have a headache nausea or vomiting, it could mean that the shunt is fractured or blocked and I would have to be operated on immediately. If not, the consequences could be fatal.  I get frequent  headaches and pains in my head around the area where the shunt is , and due to all the operations the sensitivity in my head has changed, so a daily task like having my hair washed or  brushed is more like a time of discomfort than pleasure for me, as my head is very sensitive to touch¿Que es la Hidrocefalia?  La Hidrocefalia Es  La Otra Discapacidad  Que  Tengo. Esta Sección  Explica  Más Sobre  La Hidrocefalia .  Esta Es Una Discapacidad Que  Las Personas  No Saben Que  Tengo Porque  No Es Visible La hidrocefalia es una  discapacidad de origen neurológica  en la ual, debido a una lesión cerebral (en mi caso, la severa hemorragia dentro de mi cerebro) los niveles de fluido cerebroespinal, que protegen el cerebro y la columna vertebral , son tan altos que causan el cerebro y el cráneo a hincharse. He tenido suerte en que fui intervenida rápidamente cuando sólo tenía dos semanas de vida. Fue una operación muy arriesgada porque yo era muy pequeña y prematura. La operación fue  para  poner un sistema de drenaje llamado una  válvula de derivación  dentro de mi cerebro para drenar el exceso de líquido cefaliraquideo    El sistema de drenaje es una válvula de presión conectada a un catéter (sonda) que se adentra en mi abdomen. Sólo porque tengo esto, no significa mi hidrocefalia este  curada o que haya desaparecido, no lo ha hecho. De hecho, NO hay cura para ninguna de mi discapacidades. Mi hidrocefalia se dice que esta controlado debido a la desviación, pero es como una bomba de relojería  porque  cada  vez que tengo  náuseas,  dolor de cabeza o vómitos, puede significar que la válvula de derivacion este      fracturada o bloqueada y que tendría que ser operada inmediatamente. Si no, las consecuencias podrían ser fatales. Tengo frecuentes dolores de cabeza y en mi cabeza alrededor del área donde está la desviación y debido a todas las operaciones, me  ha cambiado la sensibilidad en la cabeza, así que una tarea diaria como que alguien me lave o cepille  mi cabello es más como un momento de malestar que placer para mí, mi cabeza es muy sensible al tacto. My eyesight difficulties are nystagmus, which is a constant, uncontrolled side – to – side eye movement associated with cerebral palsy , squint in both eyes, tunnel vision and an eye condition called hemianopsia where my visual field is severely restricted because I have blindness in one half of both eyes, and so I'm working with the equivalent of one eye with very restricted eyesight doing the work of two which has always caused me a lot of difficulty focusing my eyes, eyestrain, very bad headaches and dizziness, even though I am sitting down.As as a result of all of these eye conditions due to my cerebral palsy,  and hydrocephalus , am registered legally blind. I have relied on glasses my whole life but they do not correct my vision and I am only able to see a very small amount despite the highly specialist, strong lenses I have. I rely on an electric wheelchair to get around. The tightness of my muscles causes them to cramp easily and I have muscle spasms for which I have to take daily medication. These spasms are also very painful.I have had my fair share of stares, insults and endured constant bullying during my school years.  People   have doubted and criticised   me,  and still do, but that has never stopped me, and never will . I am a person who's grown from not confident at all to believing in myself throughout the course of my life so far. After a difficult entry into the world I have always strived to fight for what I believed in, whether or not others thought I'd achieve it or not , and I am happy with what I have achieved up til now, but always look for new challenges, goals and dreams to persue. Tambien tengo estrabismo ambos   ojos, visión de túnel y una afección ocular llamada hemianopsia donde mi campo visual está severamente restringido porque tengo ceguera en la  mitad de ambos ojos y así estoy trabajando con el equivalente de un ojo con una vista muy restringida haciendo el trabajo de los dos que  siempre me causó mucha dificultad para enfocar los ojos, ademas de vista cansada, muy fuertes dolores de cabeza y mareos, aun cuando estoy sentada. Como consecuencia de todas estas condiciones de la vista  debido a mi parálisis cerebral y la hidrocefalia, estoy registrada como una persona ciega.
