CHAPTER
ONE
It was the last day of
school before the summer holiday, and Casey’s mother Carrie was getting her
ready for school. Casey, age nine, attended special school in Meadowtown,
Oxfordshire, where the family decided to live after having lived in
London.  Casey and her younger brother,
Nick, had to move school and make new friends, and had experienced many
changes  in their short lives. The
family,  who used to live in a ground floor apartment
in a modern apartment block in London, got fed up of the city,  and decided to move to a more rural
location.
Carrie Ford, a thin woman with straight brown hair down to her shoulders and
pale  blue eyes, looked  through her daughter’s drawers.
‘It’s a special day today Casey,’ she said. 
‘What do you want to wear then?’ 
Casey, who looked identical to her mother, but who wore glasses, looked up at
her mother and said.
 ‘My purple dress’ - purple was her
favourite colour - ‘and my white sandals’. 
As the day was warm, the purple dress and white sandals were a great choice.
The sandals were special ones that supported Casey’s feet well.  Casey needed to wear special sandals and
shoes, as her hips were dislocated and her feet turned in due to the cerebral
palsy she was born with.  She loved
wearing pretty clothes, as any little girl does, and her bedroom was  full of pretty things.  It was painted a lilac colour, and had
stencils of horses on the walls. Casey’s mum lifted her daughter into her
electric wheelchair using the electric hoist, an electric lifter which had a
soft harness instead of a seat  attached
to it. It was on rails that were built into the ceiling in Casey’s bedroom and
her bathroom, as it was the easiest, and safest, way of moving Casey from one place
to another without her parents having to lift her as she could not stand up or
walk because of her disability, When she was ready they went to have breakfast
with the rest of the family before the school bus arrived.
 The sun shone into the kitchen, and they saw that Casey’s father John,
and her brother,  Nick, were already
sitting at the table. 
‘Good morning Carrie, good morning Casey’ said John, kissing them both.  
John was a tall, thin  man with wavy
brown hair and blue eyes. He was reading the Business section of the newspaper
as usual, as he worked in nearby Linton as an architect, and needed to keep up
with what was going on in his type of work. 

‘Hi Mum, Hi Casey’ said Nick. 
‘Good morning Nick, darling’ said Carrie, as she kissed her son. 
‘Hi Nick’ said Casey, and they began eating their breakfast. 
Carrie only had time for a quick breakfast herself, but also found time to help
her daughter with eating meals.  Casey’s
coordination wasn’t good, and this made eating difficult for her. Casey had to
take medication with her meals. Her medication were tablets called Baclofen,
which helped relax her muscles, and Carrie had been told by Casey’s doctor and
at the chemist that they were best taken with a milky drink, as the milk would
protect Casey’s stomach. That was alright, as Casey loved drinks such as hot
chocolate for breakfast. The occupational therapist, a lady who was in charge
of helping Casey have equipment that helped her do things better, even if it
was with help,  had assessed Casey and
suggested a cup with a lid and a hole for a straw, so she could drink more
easily, and that cup was on the table now. 
 Carrie looked at her watch and turned to
her husband. 
‘Help Casey finish off breakfast please darling, I don’t want to be  late, not on the last day.’ 
Casey’s mum was a teacher at Casey’s school, Greenacres Special School, and
since her daughter was born nine years ago, she hadn’t left her side. 
‘I will’ he said,  and took the spoon
from his wife’s hand. 
Both Casey and her brother were eating Coco Pops, and her dad was eating
Shredded Wheat. The kettle was starting to boil, and he asked his children what
they wanted to drink.  They both had
orange juice, and he served himself some tea in his trademark mug with a
picture of a house on. 
He was an architect at the big company, 
Smiths, which specialised in architecture and home decor. Instead of
buying a house that was already built, he had bought land and got his
colleagues to build their house from scratch, based on plans he had drawn.  
This was always a dream of his, to build his own home for his family. It was
much better for Casey and Nick than the London apartment they’d lived in,
which, although spacious and big enough for them, it wasn’t to be their home
forever, as they wanted to have a proper family home with even more space and a
bigger garden. 
This house had it all.  It was a large,
detached house built, like many older buildings in Oxford and Oxfordshire, with
Cotswold stone. The sand-coloured bricks were more traditional and looked
better in this area than red bricks, he thought, and he and his colleagues had
planned the house very carefully, as he wanted his family to have the house
they deserved, and he had managed to give them just that. 
He gave himself a mental pat on the back as he sipped his tea, and helped his
daughter finish her cereal. They ate some muffins, and then it was time for his
seven -year-old son, Nick, to brush his teeth and be off to school. 
‘Bye Nick’ said Carrie, John and Casey as Nick got up from the table to go and
get his schoolbag.
 ‘Bye Dad’ answered Nick. ‘Bye Mum’ ‘Bye
Casey.’ 
A few minutes later, they heard the front door close and he was gone.  Nick walked to his friend Tom’s house and
they went to school together from there. 
John always waited with Casey for the school minibus, which came to the house
to collect her.  It was still 8; 30
AM.  It usually arrived at around 9 AM. .
 He took her to her own  bathroom, a large wet - room with an adapted
toilet, which had a higher seat than a usual toilet, and a bar on the wall on
either side of it for Casey´s safety. There was also an open shower area, and a
bathtub with a bath lift. The bathroom was right next to her bedroom.  Next, he found her schoolbag, a rucksack
(which was also purple). 
By the time that was done, they heard a ring on the door bell. John opened the
door and saw Sophie, one of the school’s care workers. Sophie had black hair
almost to her waist and was Casey’s helper on the bus. 
Sophie took Casey’s rucksack from John with a ‘thanks John’ and put Casey’s
wheelchair on manual to be able to push it down the shallow slope from the
front door. 
The green minibus had been paid for by the local Council, and had an electric
lift at the back for wheelchairs.  
The driver, Bill, came round to the back of the bus and  pressed the round red button on the side of
the lift to make it reach the ground. He was a kind man in his fifties, with
brown hair and glasses, who used to be an ambulance driver.  
As the lift whirred to the ground, he asked Casey and Sophie,  
‘Ready for the last day of school?’
 ‘Yes’, they both said. Sophie
stepped onto the tail lift, which was big enough for two people, and held onto
the side of Casey’s wheelchair for balance. It wasn’t long until the tail lift
reached the level with the opening of the back of the minibus, and they were
both safely inside. The minibus was spacious so as to be able to fit people in
electric wheelchairs in, and Sophie helped Bill secure Casey’s  wheelchair to the floor of the minibus with
hooks and straps after they had put her seat belt on, as every carer and mini
bus driver was fully trained beforehand to take extra special care when making
the children safe to travel in their wheelchairs. 
Not all of the children were in wheelchairs, but those who were were secured
like this. After one last, gentle tug to make sure that the wheelchair was
safe, Sophie herself sat in the seat next to Casey’s wheelchair and fastened
her seat belt. Bill returned to the front of the bus. Sophie put her hand in
Casey’s, as she knew that Casey got a bit nervous when travelling, even on the
short fifteen minute journey from the Ford house to Greenacres Special School,
as she didn’t like the  movement of the
bus as it made her feel dizzy despite the way her wheelchair was tied down.
Casey’s balance was affected by her cerebral palsy, and she had a harness to
secure her into the wheelchair which she wore all the time, not just when
travelling.
Casey looked around: the bus was almost full by the time it got to her house,
and she spotted her best friend, Rachel. 
‘Hi, Rachel!’ she said, 
‘Hi Casey’ replied Rachel, 
Rachel Brown was the same age as Casey, and had long blonde hair and blue eyes.
She was wearing a red jacket and jeans. She  sat in
a manual wheelchair and also had cerebral palsy. Casey and Rachel had
known each other for years, and their mums were best friends. They chatted
excitedly about what they were going to do at school that day, 
Casey’s favourite thing to do at school was read, and Rachel’s was, too. They
were both top of the class in reading, and they had learnt to read quickly.
Today was the end of term Book Fair, and they were both looking forward to
having a new book to read for the holidays. 
Just then, the bus pulled up to the school gates and Bill parked it in the
reserved parking space. He pushed the button to open the doors at the back of
the bus,  and put the lift down, so that
the children and the carers could get off the bus. Everybody crossed the car
park and went through the automatic doors into the building. 
The fist person Casey and Rachel saw, unfortunately, was Angela, a thin girl
with blonde curly hair, who was with her dark–haired friend, Kelly, and was a
real bully.  Angela turned her wheelchair
towards them, and said ‘so, who’s here today then? Maybe you’ll both finally
learn something seeing as it’s the last day!’ 
Sophie said ‘Angela, you’d better get to class too, don’t you think?’ 
 ‘Go away, Angela’, Casey and Rachel
said. They hoped she wouldn’t bother them for the rest of the day. 
Greenacres Special School was a modern and spacious building, and was built
only five years ago. It was a long, red brick building all on one level, and
had ramps coming out of various doors. For Carrie and John Ford, it seemed the
best choice for their daughter when they were choosing which school she’d go
to, as since being built it had been awarded 
‘excellent’ in all of its OFSTED reports. They wanted Casey to get
the best support possible in her classes. 
The school was named after the huge area of land it was built on, and had its
own outdoor swimming pool, as well as indoor hydrotherapy pool, rooms for
physical and occupational therapy, and a sensory room. All the rooms had
electric doors, and were big enough for a whole class of children in
wheelchairs. 
The teachers had hung the children’s’ paintings, artwork and stories on the
walls, which were painted bright colours. There was the reading area in one
corner, which had shelves full of books, and looked like  a mini library, and all the desks were large
enough for any type of wheelchair to fit underneath, and could be changed  in both height and angle. Casey’s and
Rachel’s desks were side-by-side.
All the children came into the class. In total, there were fifteen students in
Casey’s class, and there were four assistants. Some of the children had their
own personal assistants, like Casey did. Their teacher, Miss Honeysuckle, was
twenty five years old, but despite that had lots of experience working with
children with disabilities.  She sat at
her desk and filled out the register for the day. Everybody was in the class
today. She welcomed them and began the class.
The day consisted of using the sensory room, music, some reading and then it
was lunchtime. Diane, a tall woman with short red hair who was Casey’s
classroom assistant, accompanied her to the canteen, which was a large room
with the same tables as the classrooms. 
She got Casey’s  square purple lunchbox
out of her rucksack, then opened the door and said ‘it’s a lovely day’.
When they saw the sunshine, Casey asked
 ‘Can we eat outside? I want to eat
outside!’ 
‘Yes, me too’ said Rachel. 
‘All right  girls, let’s go outside!’
said Diane, and opened the door wider to help Casey through.  Rachel followed. They went down the ramp and
then found a large paved area by some trees. It was not very busy, so Casey,
Diane, Rachel and Rachel’s assistant Jackie had their lunch there. 
Then, suddenly, Angela appeared again, and ran her wheelchair into
Rachel’s. 
 ‘Be careful’, warned Diane, and Jackie. 
‘I can see the stupid girls are back’, said Amanda, ‘I hope you learn something
on your last day’.
 ‘Ignore her’, said the carers. When they
had finished, they went back into the school building and back into
class. 
Miss Honeysuckle told them that the Book Fair had just arrived, and that they
would go and have a look at the books. 
Casey and Rachel had beaming smiles on their faces when they heard this,
and wanted to be the first in line to go. A few minutes later, the entire class
was making its way into the school hall, where the Book Fair was held. A lot of
the books were aimed at children with disabilities, for example, there were
Braille books and large print books as well as books that could be used with e
book readers. There were also some books for adults. Casey bought The Lion
the Witch and the Wardrobe by CS Lewis, and Rachel bought a book of fairy
stories. Whilst at the Book Fair, Casey even saw her mum, who taught people
younger than Casey and Rachel. Miss Honeysuckle was busy looking at books for
her class when she saw Casey’s mum, Carrie. 

‘Carrie’ she called, ‘over here.’ 
Carrie Ford walked over to where she was standing. Ella Honeysuckle said
quietly, so as not to be overheard by the children ‘come to my classroom later,
I have a surprise up my sleeve for the children - in fact, it’s a kind of
end-of-term party’.  
‘Very interesting’ said Carrie. ‘I’ll be there in ten minutes. 
’When the Book Fair ended, she felt excitement for the children.
 She led her own class back to their
classroom. As her class of seven-year-olds put their books and rucksacks away
with the help of their assistants, she told them that they were going to see
Miss Honeysuckle’s class and off they went. 
As they reached her classroom door, Carrie knocked on it,  and was greeted by the sight of tables with
food and drink on and the classroom was decorated with streamers in different
bright colours, blue, pink, green and yellow.  There was even a banner
with ‘HAPPY SUMMER HOLIDAYS!’ written
on it, which Miss Honeysuckle herself had made. 
The children had a great  time at
the party, and then it was time to go home.   Miss Honeysuckle stopped the
party at half past two, half an hour earlier than the school day usually ended,
and said ‘and now, children, it’s time for the summer holidays!’
The children who had Personal Assistants were helped to get ready by them,
whilst the other class assistants helped clear the tables from the party and
leave the classroom tidier than it was. 
The children were smiling and happy. They were all really excited to
have time off school for the summer. 
Miss Honeysuckle cleared the rest of the food away. Because Casey’s
mother was a teacher and worked at the school, she would be allowed to take
some of the food home, but she didn’t know it yet. 
Miss Honeysuckle took Casey’s mother and a classroom Assistant of hers
called  Trisha, a black- haired
twenty-year-old, and whispered ‘help me bring all this food and drink back to
the Staffroom’, waving her hand towards 
the leftover food and drinks. Between them, they did.
The Staffroom was at the opposite end of the building. They opened the red
door  and some of the other teachers
looked at them, wondering why they had the food and drink in their hands. They
asked what they did to celebrate the end of term. When Ella and Carrie told
them about the party, many teachers thought it was a good idea, and secretly
promised themselves they’d be more imaginative next time.  
Miss Honeysuckle and Carrie put the food on the table. ‘Help yourselves’, said
Trisha. There were smiles and low giggles as some teachers did just that, some
snacking on what was left of the bags of crisps, cakes, party sausages, sausage
rolls and caffeine-free soft drinks. 
 Georgina, a teacher who’d just arrived
from, Boston, suggested sharing the food out amongst them.  All the teachers agreed this was a good idea,
as many of the teachers had children themselves, and so the food would get
eaten and not be wasted, Maggie, an Occupational Therapist, found some carrier
bags in a nearby storage cupboard, and all the teachers started sharing the
leftovers between them. There were two male teachers at the school: Ian
Wainwright and David Smith. They were both very tall, with black hair and blue
eyes.  David was eating a sausage roll
and chatting to Ian. 
‘It’s great we have some time off work now’ he said.  
‘Yes it really is’ answered Ian. 
The door opened just at that moment, and Emily Pryor, the Headmistress walked
in. Emily had long, curly red hair and brown eyes. She was petite, thin and very
bubbly. All the teachers at Greenacres Special School agreed she was the best
headmistress they’d had so far, and the school had flourished in the four years
she’d been in command.  In a way, it was
truly ‘her’ school. 
‘Having fun?’  she asked them.  
All the teachers laughed. She remembered then that she had one last surprise
for the term: she went to her locker, opened it, and took out a  bag of hand-painted  wooden photo frames. She had a real talent
for art and crafts, and had made one for each teacher. They were individually
decorated to reflect the personality of each member of her staff. She passed
them round. Each was wrapped in tissue paper the same colour as the frame
inside it. 
Carrie opened the pale yellow tissue paper surrounding hers. The frame   had
yellow sunflowers on it and, in curly painted letters, it said ‘sunny’ 
‘Aww thanks so much’ she said. 
 Then, she found a Tupperware container
in the small kitchen area of the Staffroom, and put some sausage rolls, inside
before she closed the bright red lid. She also took some crisps, six cans of
Lemon Fanta and Sprite and a bottle of caffeine-free-Coke. 
She looked at her Dolce and Gabbana watch, which John had given her last
Christmas, and said ‘right, I’d better go and get Casey.’
The teachers said their goodbyes, and she left the Staffroom. 
When she got back to the classroom, Casey was ready and waiting in her summer
coat and Diane was by her side.
 Diane gave her a hug, and said. ‘I’ll
accompany you outside.’
 She did. The school minibus was there,
Bill was waiting. 
Suddenly, Carrie said ‘Bill, Casey’s coming with me.’  
Casey said ‘why aren’t I going on the bus, Mum?’
Carrie explained  ‘I have the van with
me’.
 She’d gone home in her lunch hour, left
her car, and driven back to the school with the family’s adapted van. 
Casey’s face broke into a grin. ‘Thanks, Mum’ she said. 
The van was a great help for getting Casey around. It was a silver Fiat van
which the family had bought years ago. Carrie opened the passenger door and put
her black handbag on the seat,  and then
opened the sliding door to put the carrier bags on one of the seats so she had
her hands free to help her daughter. She pulled the ramp down, pulling the
straps tight on each side of the ramp to create a safety barrier so it would be
safer when they went up the ramp.To see more, visit my blog http://alittleblogofshortstoriesandpoems.blogspot.com.esPara ver más, visite mi blog  http://alittleblogofshortstoriesandpoems.blogspot.com.es

PLEASE NOTE:

The clock to the upper right started ticking for us at 30 days.  We immediately pulled the sight and stopped contributions until now, so we could add excerpts of "The Three Rs" to www.AmySever.com.  Please enjoy reading excerpts of 21 out of the 50 Chapters in the book.  I think you will find them very compelling.

Some excerpts are also at www.facebook.com/AmySever3Rs.  PLEASE "Like" and "Share" this page!  There are also several very helpful links on both sights.

Summary

How does a person progress from “suicidal to significance”?  And why can’t everybody that experiences tragedy, overcome that tragedy and rise to a level of great purpose?  

Everybody can!

At age 12, I watched my twin brother accidentally fall to his death.  At age 17, I was raped at knifepoint.  At 24, my first husband was killed in a car wreck.

By age 30, I had come from 5’3” and 176 lbs, to win 1st Place in the North American Nova and 2nd in the World Galaxy competitions. 

The story between those last two paragraphs is chronicled in my book “The Three Rs”.  But before you think it is a book about my success, please know it isn’t.  It is about the process I walked through from “suicidal to significance”.  The freedom I have today is available for everyone …no matter what you may have been through.

I spent a couple of years doing some  seminars, and have walked people into the same freedom …many of their stories are in the book.  But I knew I could do more. This book has been writing itself my entire life, and now I am ready.  Thank you in advance for helping me to help others.

What We Need & What You Get

My husband, Steve and I have been successful enough in a couple of Network Marketing companies that we now are able to be self-sufficient. And while that is good, just the two of us can't capitalize a project of this size.

I have had this message on hold for the past 12 years.  One reason is because we were building a business.  Another is because of the expense and time to start the project correctly.  TODAY we are able to devote full time.  AND NOW with YOU and Indiegogo, we see a way to fund it, and we're asking for your help. Every time someone walks through this information,  the results have always been extraordinary!

The Details:

The funding will be used strictly for publishing and creating the seminars.  After this initial seed funding, the profit from the book and seminars will go directly into more printings and more seminars.  The book and the first two seminars (Dallas and Sydney) will be promoted to our friends and family that know us from business in the US and Australia.  This is what we need to begin:

  • $13,750 is for publishing and the initial printing.  It includes book cover, interior design, editing, formatting and the initial run.
  • $8,500 is to develop the seminar material and printing the workbooks.  This money is also to secure the rights to the movie clips I will use in the seminar to reinforce the information.  These are powerful and really enhance the message.
  • $4,750 will open the doors to the first 2-day Dallas seminar in March of 2014.
  • $6,500 will allow us to do the 2-day seminar in Sydney in May of 2014.  (The cost of living in AU is a bit higher.)
  • $2,500 to produce the first master of the audiobook.  I will narrate it.  My husband Steve will produce and edit it, so all we are having to pay for here is music rights and some materials.  The audiobook will be ready in April of 2014.

The Perks!  ...are listed to the side.  The biggest perk is MY HEARTFELT THANKS and the THANKS of the unlimited number of people you are about to help!  We will thank you by name on www.AmySever.com.  We will list the names of every contributor in every seminar workbook on the thank you page entitled, "These Are The People That Made Your Freedom Possible Today!"

The rest of the Perks detailed to the right include personalized copies of the book, audiobook, seminar attendance, scholarships for others to attend a seminar (those who need it but can't afford it), and personal time together with Steve and me.

The Impact

This book will have a major impact.  How can I say that?  Because I have watched this material have a permanent, positive effect on so many people! Not only that, but many of those people have taken the material and used it with others, AND achieved the same results!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute?  You can still help us have a HUGE impact!  
Share  www.AmySever.com with everyone you know.  
Share and Like my facebook page,  www.facebook.com/AmySever3Rs.

I am embarking on a ministry that I have been running from for 12 years.  When you read the Prologue and some of the excerpts of the book, you will understand why...  

I will be doing weekly calls on Blog Talk Radio to update you and on the details of this unfolding ministry AND to minister to anyone who calls in for help.

Mostly, Steve and I covet your prayers.  Thank you for your support in this most important way! 

~ Amy Sever

story:
The debut nonfiction work of architect, artist, writer, and performance researcher Monika Ponjavić.


Film Curation: From the Black Box to the Black Box of a White Cube takes a closer look at the new, emerging curatorial practice, called film curation. Case studies for the work are the exhibition Found Footage: Cinema Exposed (2012) curated by Dutch curator Jaap Guldemond that took place at the Film Institute Eye in Amsterdam and video installation 24 Hours Psycho(1993) by Scottish artist Douglas Gordon (with a closer look at  several of his video works such as Fog, Confession of a Justified Sinner, etc.) Juxtaposing the exhibition (of the works done in found footage and Postproduction Art) with the video installation (done in found footage and Postproduction Art) her intention was to explore to what extent are the blurred lines of demarcation between art and curation actually blurred. In doing so she confronted the film narrative (of the work exhibited) and the narration of the exhibition, questioning the authorial role of the artist and the curator, as well as the process in which artist and curator work, respectively.


This project lost its funding due to the devastating floods in the Balkans. We need your help for the final mile.

story:
Short Summary

My wife and I have always loved books, and since we were beginner readers we knew we would grow up surrounded by them. While my vision was a bit vague and I would always say I wanted to be a storyteller, Amanda has dreamed of being an author from the very start. She went to school, got bit by an anaconda in Peru, left school, became a wife and mother, wrote books and had them published, went on the road to sell her books, had two publishing houses fold up, created her own publishing house, went through a traumatic divorce, wrote another book, built up her publishing house into a global community of authors, artists, and editors, got remarried, and is now opening a bookstore and art gallery. So she has some stories to tell!

Through all this, one of our children has become confined to a wheelchair and another is on the autism spectrum, so being on the road and selling books at far away events every weekend has become impossible. Line by Lion Publishing, our publishing house, represents not only our dream but also the dreams of authors who have their own amazing stories to tell. Rather than give up or declare it to be too difficult, we chose to transition to a brick-and-mortar store where independent authors can reach the public alongside local art and music.

With your contributions, we can make this dream (so many people's dreams) come true in a big way. Not only in a practical sense of creating a place of home-away-from home surrounded by creativity, or seeing a book go from idea to finished product in the hand of a customer, but also in the much larger sense of being able to show our four children (and children everywhere) that dreams are worth pursuing and are achievable outside of cheesy movies!

What We Need & What You Get

Funding will go toward the basic introductory necessities: rent, renovations, transferring utilities and paying for stock to make sure this bookstore can become a reason people visit Frankfort Avenue (or maybe a reason to come to Louisville! - we have big dreams). We are asking for $5000 because we understand any adventure comes with a lot of surprises and we want to be prepared for things we can't even see coming, yet. We are turning this bookstore into a comfortable place where people can feel at home, which means repainting old walls, rearranging bookshelves (and a LOT of books), and decorating everything from the ceiling to the walls to the street space outside. We will also be providing entertainment like character actors, live music, and signing events by beloved or brand new authors year round. We are a small business in the creative field, we know that people in the creative arts can die of 'exposure' and we intend to properly support those that bring life to our store.

We are giving back to the community, but in a more direct sense, we want to give back to you with special perks for your donation. There will be a pack of 4x6 postcards with images from the art gallery, art from Charlotte & Daisy (the novel by Amanda Lamkin, author and publisher and owner of The Roar-Shack), and commemorative photos from the grand opening. For higher-tier perks, we will be offering t-shirts or other swag items so you can brag to the world about how you helped make this lion roar. For those that truly give of their heart, and want to know they had a big part of making dreams come true, we have a special treat: a half-hour professional photo session with a photographer and graphic artist who will capture you or your family wearing your favorite costume from your favorite story (movie or book), and one image from the shoot will be edited to look like it came right from the pages or screen.

Though we dream big, we understand things don't always work exactly as planned. In the event that we don't reach our full goal, we are working with IndieGoGo to still make use of the funds that you do provide! Our top priority will be the basic necessities of keeping the shop open, paying bills and employees, and providing that atmosphere of welcoming and safety which is critical to our ideals. Even if you are not able to give very much, we want you to know that we are grateful for all the support of our family, friends, and fans. Please come to our events, find a new story (or an old friend), and discover the art gallery and local music we will feature.

 

The Impact

As was said before, this bookstore means we can give our publishing house a home. We will be selling used and new books, and we will have a special section devoted to those books we have discovered and worked so hard over to bring to life. Here you can see what an independent publisher can do (fun fact: we're too big to be called a 'small press publisher' anymore!), from developmental editing to cleanup to cover art and distribution. Does that sound like a great thing for authors? It is! But it's also great for readers. There's a lot of repetition in the big name publishing houses - they know what formula works and they're going to stick with it because they have a lot of overhead that they need to pay for. We have the benefit of finding the unusual stories, the ones with the fun twists or the unexpected take. These stories deserve their spot on the shelf, and we will make sure they get it even if we have to create a bookstore around that shelf! But seriously, we love books that feel fresh and real and tell stories we can relate to in worlds that are just a little different from ours - or really weird.

Along with this, we're not creating a library. There's no reason for awkward, hushed voices in a bookstore where pirate music is playing, coffee is brewing, the shopcat has just knocked over the business cards again, and Gandalf just walked through the young-adult section. The Roar-Shack will be a place of comfort, meeting friends, attending fun events, and ALSO discovering music, art, and of course books. We long for the day when we hear someone casually remark "Hey, let's go to The Roar-Shack, and then we can go get something to eat at the other shops on Frankfort."  Or "I'm going to The Roar-Shack before flamenco classes, wanna come?" Trust me, Frankfort Avenue is already a fascinating destination. We just want to be a reason you go there again, or the reason you discovered it in the first place.

Don't listen to the nay-sayers who mutter that books are going out of style. E-books are great, and we sell those too, but nothing will replace the feel, weight, and fragrance of a real novel in your hands. Someone once said: "Seeing someone reading a book you love is seeing a book recommending a person." We connect with novels, and reading an old-fashioned page-turner says something about you to the people around you. (Sometimes it says you're pretentious, so be careful.) Studies show that while e-readers are popular, a rising majority of people prefer keeping or rediscovering the joy of reading from a paper book. We are not worried about going out of style. Even while big name book stores are struggling to find their place, we understand that readers are looking for that connection to the author and to each other - not some gimmick or sterile experience along the lines of picking up something from the pharmacy. The Roar-Shack is a timeless sort of place, and we know it will be a successful component in our community.

Risks & Challenges

This won't be easy! We're talking about a new business, shaking up expectations, and working with a lot of other small businesses that will all be leaning on each other for support and cooperation. No adventure is easy. They wouldn't call it an adventure, then. That would just be...chores, or something.

We are starting out as a two-person team. We already have friends and coworkers stepping up to fill roles, but ultimately it falls on one married couple to make this work. The publishing house was very similar (I started out as a fan, then became Amanda's cover artist, and eventually creative director. Then, later, I asked her to marry me. She likes to call it reverse nepotism.) This challenge is being met daily, though! Your support in this campaign won't be going toward any new hires, but showing up and telling your friends to show up and make our bookstore successful will! We have a budget in place and a growth plan to extend hours with a team of fun and reliable employees. What good is a bookstore if it closes when you leave work?

The other challenge is, of course, reminding people that it is okay to enjoy reading. It has become a little fashionable to sniff and announce that you don't read. Over the years, we have acquired friends in all sorts of fields who love to read like we do. As a bonus, popular culture has been devouring our favorite sci-fi and fantasy novels and turning them into major Hollywood movies. Together with fans, we plan to have events with costumed characters, reading times, storytelling, and musical shenanigans where people can come and enjoy themselves and see just how much can be found inside the pages of these books surrounding them.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't despair if you don't have the money to chip in right now. Tell everyone about this new adventure, make plans to come and see us, and tell us what you enjoy reading so we can help you find that old classic you've been missing or introduce you to a new voice you'll love!

Conversations around the coffee pot work great, but don't forget to use all of the social media. Share this campaign! Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, even the Indiegogo sharing tools. Get the word out so this can be the most successful grand opening ever. We're counting on you!

story:
Le projet

La famille Notre Dame d’Orient et d’Occident organise un pèlerinage à destination des chrétiens orientaux résidant en France. Ce pèlerinage ira jusqu’à Rome à l’occasion de la canonisation de Jean- Paul II le 27 avril prochain. SOS chrétiens d’Orient dont le convoi humanitaire Noël en Syrie vient d’être couronné de succès a décidé de soutenir cette initiative afin de ne pas oublier les chrétiens orientaux qui vivent aujourd’hui en France souvent pour échapper à des persécutions.

Nous vous proposons de contribuer à ce pèlerinage en apportant un soutien matériel et spirituel. Chaque jour notre site www.auservicedeschrétiensorientaux.fr publiera une réflexion spirituelle qui sera un appel à prier pour que ce pèlerinage soit une occasion d’enrichissement et, peut-être, de réconfort pour les participants.

Mais ce projet ne pourra pas se réaliser sans le parrainage auquel nous vous invitons.

Nous vous proposons de suivre concrètement un des participants en assumant les frais de son expédition romaine mais également en entretenant avec lui un suivi fraternel dans l’échange et le partage. Nous sommes convaincus que cette expérience sera une œuvre d’enrichissement mutuel comme nous l’enseigna Jean-Paul II :

« Dans l’effort d’approfondissement de la vérité révélée, les méthodes et les moyens de connaître et d’exprimer les choses divines ont été différents en Orient et en Occident. Il n’est donc pas étonnant que certains aspects du mystère révélé aient été parfois mieux saisis et mieux exposés par l’un que par l’autre, si bien que ces diverses formules théologiques doivent souvent être considérées comme plus complémentaires qu’opposées »

story:
Deeply Rooted Magazine is an independent, quarterly publication geared towards Christ-following wives and moms. We use beautiful imagery, clean design, and scripturally-sound articles to show our readers how the Gospel is woven into every aspect of being a woman, wife, and mom. Our goal through this campaign is to raise funding for the government applications that allow us to incorporate and become a non-profit, as well as the ability to print our very first issue! Our biggest goal is to distribute this magazine to as many Christian women as possible.

We have six sections within our magazine, each based off of roles we carry as women:

  • Christ-follower (Christian living and theology -- ultimately woven into all categories)
  • Help-mate (Marriage)
  • Mother (Parenting)
  • Creator (Artistry and DIY)
  • Keeper of the Home (Homemaking)
  • Individual (Hobbies, Career, Service, and Ministry)


Here's what fans have said so far about our magazine:

"I was truly blessed by this sample edition of the magazine! Thank you, ladies, for using your talents to minister to the Body. I'm so excited about what God is going to do through you all."

". . .when she posted something about deeply rooted, my heart skipped a beat. I have been looking around lately thinking, 'Why are there so many magazines celebrating a false reality? So many artists creating work that is based on an illusion, rather than the messy, imperfect, beautiful, God-woven, raw life we are all living?' -- and then, here you are!"

"Very excited about your new mag! It's right up my alley . . . I'm sure it will be a blessing to many!"

"It is amazing what you guys are doing. Yes, we all want pretty things . . .but if we don't know our purpose and our Creator, it's pointless. Society today has made it so difficult for Christians to focus and do what we are called to do and I feel as though the enemy is working double time to try to distract everyone from the real deal . . . We need more magazines, companies, businesses like this."

WHAT WE NEED

We are not here to make money. Our goal is that by becoming a religious non-profit and having the ability to accept tax-deductible donations, we will be able to make our digital publication free to anyone and off-set the expensive cost of printing.

Our goal is to raise $11,200 and as you see in our fabulous pie chart, most of the expenses go toward the product you receive from your contributions. There are costs needed beyond this figure, but we tried to boil it down to the most essential needs because this is an all or nothing campaign. If we do not reach our funding goal, we will not receive any funding and all contributions will be refunded. We trust in God's full provision and ask you to consider giving. By investing in our cause, you are changing hearts and lives.

WHAT YOU GET

If you look at the right sidebar, you will see the different reward levels for each contribution. Each reward includes sales tax and shipping (with the exception of inter national shipping.)


At $50, you receive this eco-friendly tote along with a print and digital copy of our first issue. It beautifully displays the hand-lettered verse, Colossians 2:6-7, our magazine verse. This tote is made of thick, 12-ounce cotton canvas that is made of natural, biodegradable material and is dyed a dark navy color. The dark color means it won't get dirty as easily, which we know is a must for moms especially! The size is 11" x 14" x 5" with an extra long handle. It's perfect for carrying books, our magazines, and anything else you may want to throw in there.

If you give the first $300 donation, you will receive this one-of-a-kind wood-burned art which has been generously donated by Hand-Lettering Co. This 16.25"x14" was carefully crafted by hand. It beautifully displays our magazine's verse, Colossians 2:6-7. Along with it, you will receive our eco-friendly tote, a printed copy and a digital copy.

THE NEED

Pinterest is proof that women are searching. It could be a workout plan, a perfectly curated wardrobe, or a collection of self-help quotes. If you untangle all the webs, you will find one common denominator and that is the desire to improve self and quality of life. Unfortunately, many Christian women are caught in the under-current of it all. Deeply Rooted Magazine serves to battle the things in life that work overtime to steal our attention and affection away from God. We strive to deliver incredibly-rich content, written and created by published authors, real life women, and talented artists. Our Gospel-centered articles are filled with practical application, forming a magazine that will encourage, inspire, and challenge you with solid, Biblical truth.

There are a lot of great, Christian resources out there, but many people never pick them up because of the way they look. People judge a book by its cover and in today's age, high quality design is important. On the other hand, there are many well-designed publications out there, but the content is lacking. We haven't found a Christian publication that provides both: the scripturally-sound content and good design. We want to change that.

THE REWARD

We have already received an overwhelming response to our cause. So many women have written us and commented about how they have been encouraged by our social media posts and sample issue. We are excited that there are women out there that want to be "deeply rooted" women and that will translate into their marriage, parenting, relationships, and home.

Not only does this magazine bless the consumer, it also blesses the people on staff and contributing. We have 40 writers, artists, staff members, and guest contributors for our first issue and each one of them have expressed how grateful they are for the ability to use their gifts of writing, painting, designing, etc. for such a great cause. These people are published authors, stay at home moms, pastors, renowned photographers, and much more. Beyond that, they all share in our vision and want to be a part of this movement.


The central idea of our magazine for 2014 is: Becoming Deeply Rooted. This takes hold in the following themes for the year: seed, plant, branch and root. In order to become a deeply rooted woman, we need to start at the very beginning: seed to root. This concept is woven throughout all our articles. 

Here are some things you can expect to read in our first issue:

  • Articles like "What is Theology and Why Should I Care?" and "Planting Seeds Through Evangelism"
  • Several recipes and DIY projects
  • Book reviews, testimonies, and more
  • Images/designs from several renowned photographers, illustrators, and painters to coincide with each piece.

Our magazine is set apart from many other Christian publications in many ways:

  • CLEAN DESIGN & AD-FREE - We want you to be able to focus on the content and images without getting distracted by something that is screaming for your attention. 
  • PERFECT BINDING - Unlike many saddle-stiched magazines which have fewer page numbers, thinner paper, and are stitched/stapled, perfect binding glues the edges of the pages to the spine giving the magazine a more polished look and feel.
  • HEAVIER PAPER - All 96-pages are printed on high-quality, offset-opaque paper with a dull-matte 130# cover.

We understand that not everyone can give. There are still other ways you can help.

SPREAD THE WORD

The more buzz we create about Deeply Rooted, the greater chance we will reach our goal and reach the hearts of women across the world. You have the power to reach social circles that we can't, and when you tweet, share this link, and blog about what we are trying to accomplish, you help us out tremendously. Please share!

PRAY

Pray specifically for our writers and staff, for God's provision through this campaign, and that His will would be done. 

Thank you so much for considering giving to our campaign. May we all become deeply rooted in our faith!

 Don't forget, if we don't reach our goal we will not receive any funding! Please use the "SHARE" buttons to help spread the word!

Beyond that, they all share in our vision and want to be a part of this movement.The central idea of our magazine for 2014 is: Becoming Deeply Rooted. This takes hold in the following themes for the year: seed, plant, branch and root. In order to become a deeply rooted woman, we need to start at the very beginning: seed to root. This concept is woven throughout all our articles. Here are some things you can expect to read in our first issue:
Articles like "What is Theology and Why Should I Care?" and "Planting Seeds Through Evangelism"

Several recipes and DIY projects
Book reviews, testimonies, and more
Images/designs from several renowned photographers, illustrators, and painters to coincide with each piece.

Our magazine is set apart from many other Christian publications in many ways:
CLEAN DESIGN & AD-FREE - We want you to be able to focus on the content and images without getting distracted by something that is screaming for your attention. 
PERFECT BINDING - Unlike many saddle-stiched magazines which have fewer page numbers, thinner paper, and are stitched/stapled, perfect binding glues the edges of the pages to the spine giving the magazine a more polished look and feel.
HEAVIER PAPER - All 96-pages are printed on high-quality, offset-opaque paper with a dull-matte 130# cover.
We understand that not everyone can give. There are still other ways you can help.SPREAD THE WORDThe more buzz we create about Deeply Rooted, the greater chance we will reach our goal and reach the hearts of women across the world. You have the power to reach social circles that we can't, and when you tweet, share this link, and blog about what we are trying to accomplish, you help us out tremendously. Please share!PRAYPray specifically for our writers and staff, for God's provision through this campaign, and that His will would be done. Thank you so much for considering giving to our campaign. May we all become deeply rooted in our faith! Don't forget, if we don't reach our goal we will not receive any funding! Please use the "SHARE" buttons to help spread the word!

story:
What is Post trying to do?

The Post Collective was set up in 2013 as an alternative voice in Scottish politics and publishing. Its aim is to provide a voice of Scotland's younger generation on issues of environment, technology, politics and the internet not covered by the mainstream press. In the run up to the 2014 independence referendum we want to publish a book outlining new visions of sustainability, democracy, architecture and long-term thinking that goes beyond politics and beyond constitution. Thirty years down the line, in 2044, how far will we have come? What would an ideal Scotland look like, and could it become a model of progress for others to follow?


In short essays from figures including the academic Kirsteen Shields, architect Andy Summers, journalist and equality campaigner Jacq Kelly, Patrick Harvie MSP and the urbanist Stacey Hunter, Post's third printed release seeks to provide a blueprint for something different that everyone can understand. Over a hundred custom-designed pages, the contributors sketch out ideas for Scotland's next thirty years.

The full list of contributions is listed below:


  • Stacey Hunter, Architecture PhD student at the University of Edinburgh,  on new towns for Scotland.
  • Patrick Harvie, Scottish Green MSP, on the importance of protecting and expanding the public internet and civil liberties.
  • Jacq Kelly, former journalist and equality activist on what equality means in modern Scotland.
  • Laurie Macfarlane, economist and member of the Post Collective, maps out some first steps towards a fair and sustainable economy.
  • Kirsteen Shields, lecturer in public law at the University of Dundee, on how how Scotland might change its laws to protect rights to basic freedoms.
  • Lee Bunce, co-founder of Post, maps out what a democratic media landscape might look like in the internet age.
  • Ellen Young, member of the Post Collective and scientific communicator, thinks about the social benefits of education and research in a modern Scotland.
  • Oliver Escobar, researcher at the University of Edinburgh, describes ways in which methods of participatory democracy might take government closer to people.
  • Lucy Brown, energy campaigner, on renewables, people, corporations and community.
  • Dominic Hinde, co-founder of Post, journalist and translator on culture, arts and the Northern nation.
  • Peter Matthews, lecturer in the School of the Built Environment at Heriot-Watt University, on how decentralisation and the transfer of power from the capital to urban centers can be used to radically change how people interact with the state.
  • Andy Summers, photographer and architect, thinks about what the next 30 years will mean for how Scotland looks, feels and expresses itself.

What we need to make it happen

This campaign seeks to raise enough money to print Scotland 44 and stage an event around it. 1000 pounds will help us pay initial printing costs and will also allow us to buy ISBN numbers from Nielsen, the company that coordinates the system of buying and selling books. Any extra money raised will go back into the Post Collective's future projects.

All donations are welcome, but donations of over five pounds will mean you receive a copy of Scotland 44 and will be acknowledged as one of our crowdfunders in its pages. Larger donations to the project will result in you being listed as an official backer on our website and being thanked at the book's release party this summer.

Why now?

This is a critical time for Scotland, and a critical time for its publishers and media. By supporting Post you will be making a valuable contribution to the sustainability of a diverse and independent media without any political affiliation.

You can find out more about all our work on www.postmag.org , or follow us @postmag

story:
Dear Generous Souls,

Well! At the halfway mark of the campaign and it's been a valuable learning experience!

Had an interruption of focus due to my 89-year-old dad's unexpected passing on Sept. 20th, but am back with his spirit watching over things.

My name is Paulette Dahl and like most of you, I've had my share of challenge and celebration. I've raised three amazing sons over the past 20 years as a single mom, attended university and completed a double concentration degree in Gerontology and Theatre Arts.

For the past 10+ years, I've been blessed to work full-time in Social Services, helping low-income individuals as an Employment Counsellor. As a Certified Life Coach outside of work, I use an intuitive approach when dealing with people who want to Love-the-World-Large (starting with themselves).

I'm so excited and grateful to be able to share my passion for writing with you! Extraordinary Loving for Everyday Living is the first in a series of Love Letters books, which I wrote about the 'feeling life.'

Actually, it's more accurate to say that the book wrote itself through me. Have you ever had that experience? The one where you were so enthused about and connected to something so much greater than yourself that the painting, writing, song, dance or words flowed through you?

And you emerged from the creative experience as if you were in another world?  With your contribution, this world will be available to everyone.

When was the last time you wrote a letter? Or read one? Do you remember what it felt like to read something so personally relevant and profound that you wanted to read and reread it? Do you remember how you felt and how much you were loved? Or how much you wanted to reply, especially if you felt misunderstood or impassioned by the information?

Feelings are important indicators of our internal state. When they're sometimes 'yukky,' they can over-power most of the 'yummy' emotions and drive our decisions and outcomes in directions that take us away from our Selves. Providing a balance helps us focus on what is working and gives us pause to celebrate feelings that may be taken for granted.


For example, a Love Letter About the Grumpies could generate a meaningful dialogue within and between us. And the counter-balancing Love Letter With Gratitude offers us the opportunity to shift our perspective and hear how the power team of Love'n'Gratitude, Gratitude'n'Love makes change happen!

Gven a chance, this book will put these messages of Love into the hands of those who need it most: people who may be challenged by and also want to celebrate the 'feeling life.'  By randomly opening the book and reading the messages found there, they can feel comforted...and loved. And we are so loved! Even when we're not our best Selves. Especially when we're not feeling or acting our best. Let this first book light the way, as a beacon that draws you back to 'you.'

Thank you, for joining with me to ignite extraordinary loving for everyday living!

Know that I am so happy and grateful for the gift of your time and attention...and for the gift of YOU!

Sharing Gratitude'n'Love,

Paulette

What We Need & What You Get

Now that you know 'why,' I'd like to explain 'how.' 

I've already completed the manuscript and self-publishing is the route I'm taking to get this message out into the world. That means that all of the services that would be provided by a publisher (through a book contract) is my financial responsibility.

I've secured award-winning book cover designer Nick Zelinger (NZ Graphics) and his cover perfectly captures the feeling of this project! He is also doing the interior book lay-out design. Laura E. Young & Kim Fahner (editing), Greg Tremblay (video promotion), Dr. Judith Briles (The Book Shepherd/Author U Extravaganza) and Joel Friedlander (The Book Designer) have also been instrumental in preparing me for publishing success.

Your contribution will continue to pay for the services of quality professionals, so that you will enjoy a top-quality book. It still requires publishing, marketing, distribution and book tour management. I've invested more than $3,000 of my own funds so far, so I'm committed.

If my goal is exceeded, funds will then go towards preparing and producing the second and third in the series of Love Letters books (about relationships and spirituality), a website design (and someone to maintain it), designing workshops, speaking engagements and enhanced advertising of my life coaching service (Lovin'-U-Large Life Coaching).

If my goal is not met, all funds will still be used to publish my book. It will just take longer. But why wait?

Not only will you be able to feel that you have been part of a Lovin'-the-World-Large movement with your contribution, you will also enjoy some unique and spiffy perks!

Please see the 'Perks' section for a more detailed account of what you will receive, since there are rewards for 7 levels of giving and a whole lotta Love'n'Gratitude I wish to share!

LOVIN'-U-LARGE LIFE COACHING TESTIMONIAL:

When I started with Paulette Dahl, I did not know anything about Life Coaching. I called her because she is a friend of mine and I needed help with a career transition. I had a few opportunities to make changes and did not know where to start.

Paulette really helped me think through things and then take measures to get results. She was firm as needed but also very sensitive and helpful. I am much more relaxed these days and doing better. It was a difficult process for me, but Paulette made it better with her patience and support. I did not realize that the patterns of behaviour that affected my professional life were the exact same patterns that affected my personal life. When Paulette helped me explore the connection, I was able to improve all aspects of my life.

I am embarking on a new part of my life now and I feel like a door has been opened to a greater awareness. I cannot thank Paulette enough for the wonderful insight, so beautifully worded and the support and encouragement and belief in me!

R.M., Sudbury, ON

An added BONUS!! When I reach my goal, there will be an additional gift for the first 100 contributors who donate $100 or more! You will receive a creative and original Extraordinary Loving for Everyday Living 2015 Thot-Full Calendar, filled with amazing photographs (some of which are in the video) and Thots!! Copyright 2014/2015 Paulette Dahl (writer) and Jeanine Middleton (photographer). This will be sent out in November.

Follow me on Twitter: Paulette Dahl @Thotsfortheday.

With all of the challenges of delays and setbacks, I am even more prepared to celebrate that extraordinary loving IS for everyday living.

Everyone needs Love. Fuel the Love. Change the world.

Lovin'-U-Large,

Paulette

story:
IL CONTESTO

Oaxaca è il secondo Stato più povero del Messico e quello con il più alto numero di gruppi indigeni. L'alto tasso di disuguaglianza sociale ed economica fa sì che molti gruppi sociali rimangano isolati dalla comunità e vivano in condizioni di povertà e/o di emarginazione. I “Pepenadores” formano uno di questi gruppi, con standard di vita al di sotto della linea della povertà, a causa del contesto dove vivono: la discarica di Oaxaca. Tra zanzare e cani randagi, siringhe infette, malattie e mancanza di acqua corrente, uomini e donne, bambini e bambine, vivono la loro vita nella spazzatura. Quaranta famiglie, 160 persone, si addentrano nella montagna di rifiuti indifferenziati ogni giorno per 10 ore, a caccia di cartone, ferro vecchio, plastica e vetro. Tutti materiali da poter raccogliere e separare per poterli così rivendere. Esposti a incidenti, ferite, morsi di cani, punture d’insetti, liquidi tossici e polvere, i ‘Pepenadores’ riescono a racimolare mediamente la cifra di 1,50 euro al giorno, a famiglia.

NOI IN MESSICO

Curiosi di conoscere questa realtà, siamo partiti per Oaxaca de Juarez, la capitale dello Stato di Oaxaca. I fondatori della ONG SiKanda, Aurelia e Carlos, ci hanno ospitato per due mesi, durante i quali abbiamo conosciuto i Pepenadores, lavorato insieme ai volontari dell’organizzazione e incontrato molte persone straordinarie. Con questo libro, vorremmo trasmettere ai lettori l’intensità della nostra esperienza, facendo conoscere il più possibile la realtà dei Pepenadores, attraverso le loro stesse parole. Persone che davanti alle difficoltà non si danno mai per vinte, in un luogo dove solidarietà e aiuto reciproco sono i valori cardine. La storia che raccontiamo è anche una storia di donne che, in una società molto machista, sono riuscite a guadagnare autorità, conquistandosi la fiducia delle colleghe e dei colleghi di lavoro e degli altri membri della loro comunità. E' la storia del cammino di SiKanda, una piccola organizzazione nata dalla volontà di due persone che hanno scelto di lavorare con soggetti con i quali nessun’altra associazione, fino ad allora, aveva voluto lavorare.

CHI SIAMO
Milena e Andrea. Animati dalla voglia di dare un contributo concreto ai Pepenadores e a SiKanda, abbiamo deciso di raccontare la realtà messicana che abbiamo vissuto attraverso le nostre parole, cercando così di trasmettere quelle stesse emozioni che abbiamo provato accanto alla comunità di riciclatori della città di Oaxaca.   

CHI E' SIKANDA
Solidaridad Internacional Kanda - SiKanda (www.si-kanda.org), è un’organizzazione non governativa, non profit, laica e indipendente, fondata nel 2009 a Oaxaca de Juarez (Oaxaca, Messico) da Aurelia Annino (italiana di Spoleto, Perugia) e José Carlos León Vargas (messicano di Oaxaca). SiKanda ha la missione di facilitare e condurre processi partecipativi di sviluppo armonico e autosostenibile per migliorare la qualità di vita delle persone in Messico e in altre nazioni. Da quando è nata, accompagna i Pepenadores (riciclatori informali che vivono e lavorano nella discarica municipale) in un cammino verso l'uscita dalla povertà.

STATO DELL'ARTE
La prima stesura della pubblicazione è stata ultimata e sottoposta a revisione da parte di un amico scrittore, La pubblicazione si compone di un centinaio di pagine suddivise in 7 Capitoli e 6 Sottocapitoli (oltre alla Prefazione, all’Introduzione e alle Conclusioni). In ognuno di essi, alla voce dei fondatori di SiKanda, che raccontano le loro vicissitudini, segue l'intervista ad un membro (o ad una famiglia) della comunità dei Pepenadores, che raccontano la loro vita quotidiana e le difficili condizioni nella società messicana. L'opera inoltre contiene alcune pagine fotografiche, con gli scatti gentilmente concessi dalla fotografa professionista inglese Hannah Maule-Ffinch.

OBIETTIVO
Grazie ad alcuni sponsor locali abbiamo raccolto qualche centinaio di euro, perciò il nostro obiettivo qui è quello di raccogliere 2.000 euro per raggiungere la cifra necessaria alla stampa di 500/1000 copie del libro. 

Se riuscissimo a mettere insieme una cifra superiore, faremmo realizzare una traduzione dell’opera in spagnolo-messicano, in modo tale da poterla condividere con i Pepenadores e i loro concittadini.

COME PUOI AIUTARCI
Anche con un piccolo contributo si può sostenere l'iniziativa, destinata completamente ai Pepenadores. Il ricavato della vendita del libro sarà infatti interamente destinato ai progetti di SiKanda, che dal 2009 affianca la comunità di riciclatori informali in un cammino verso l'uscita dalla povertà.

ultimata e sottoposta a revisione da parte di un amico scrittore, La pubblicazione si compone di un centinaio di
pagine suddivise in 7 Capitoli e 6 Sottocapitoli (oltre alla Prefazione, all’Introduzione e alle
Conclusioni). In ognuno di essi, alla voce dei fondatori di SiKanda, che raccontano le loro vicissitudini, segue l'intervista ad un membro (o ad una famiglia) della comunità dei Pepenadores, che raccontano la loro vita quotidiana e le difficili condizioni nella società messicana. L'opera inoltre contiene alcune pagine fotografiche, con gli scatti gentilmente concessi dalla fotografa professionista inglese Hannah Maule-Ffinch.OBIETTIVOGrazie ad alcuni sponsor locali abbiamo raccolto qualche centinaio di euro, perciò il nostro obiettivo qui è quello di raccogliere 2.000 euro per raggiungere la cifra necessaria alla stampa di 500/1000 copie del libro. Se riuscissimo a mettere insieme
una cifra superiore, faremmo realizzare una traduzione dell’opera in
spagnolo-messicano, in modo tale da poterla condividere con i Pepenadores
e i loro concittadini.COME PUOI AIUTARCIAnche con un piccolo contributo si può sostenere l'iniziativa, destinata completamente ai Pepenadores. Il ricavato della vendita del libro sarà infatti interamente destinato ai progetti di SiKanda, che dal 2009 affianca la comunità di riciclatori informali in un cammino verso l'uscita dalla povertà.

story:
The Story

I've written about and worked with domestic animals all my life; more than 2,500 magazine and newspaper articles, six books and counting... 


One day, it dawned on me that I didn't really know why and how they came to live with us. So, I set off to find out.


Of the 60,000 vertebrate animal species, we've managed to domesticate a mere 50. They are, in a word, extraordinary. But why did they give up their wild freedom to come to our campfires? What did they get and give up to live alongside us? This book will answer these and many other questions, plus give amusing and meaningful insights into the animals that share our homes and barnyards.


The Impact

Millions of unwanted dogs and cats euthanized each year. Dairy cows maximized for production, then milked to death. Physical defects perpetuated throughout the horse industry. Our breeding decisions (or lack of them) impact domestic animals before they even take their first breaths. Yet ethical breeding is an almost unexplored area both in the animal industries and among animal welfare organizations. COMING TO THE FIRE will be a pioneer in this new frontier of animal welfare and well-being. 


What We Need & What You Get

I need your help for research, for up-to-date books, for office expenses and to travel to locations and get first-hand stories and reportage on topics essential to this book. Specifically, I will visit factory dairy farms in California and their family-owned organic equivalents in the Pacific Northwest; state-of-the-art horse breeding facilities in Texas; veterinary schools and clinics plus the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in New York. A dream would be to go to Siberia to interview biologists who carried out the Farm Fox Experiment, the most significant behavioral biology study of the 20th Century.


Depending on what you give, you get to pre-order a first-edition book and other great gifts (see right-hand column). But mainly, your dollars and/or time will help make lives better for the animals that serve us in so many ways.


Other Ways You Can Help

Give all you can - but also, share this project with at least FIVE PEOPLE WHO CARE ABOUT ANIMALS! Learn more about the book at: www.comingtothefire.com

story:
*UPDATE*

 

The lovely folk at Indiego have given this campaign another life line. Yay!

A Summary

Dexter is a slightly different member of our global family. He's an enigma, the type of guy you would want to have with you on a fishing expedition - merely because he would make the hours of waiting, hook and sinker, bearable by the virtue of his quirkiness. He views the world through somewhat tinted glasses but does not shy away from putting his mark, whether in form of opinion or advice, on every little detail he comes across. He is curious like a cat and just as alluring. Give him some time, he will amaze (and intrigue) you.

I have been writing about him since 2005 and collected all of the stories that ensued on my blog http://youniverses-us.blogspot.co.nz/ - until one day a very dear friend of mine prompted me to compile them all and make a book out of them. I did all of the art work associated with the book (cover image and internal exposes) myself. As a means to put this out 'legitimately,' I started my own publishing company (CVR Press Ltd) and released the first eBook on Amazon under a pseudonym, Dan Tefern (comprised of my favourite boy's name 'Dante' and my favourite plant, the 'fern',) in late November of last year: http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00A6L8L6S.

In the first months, the book managed to land several times in the top 100 'best political humour' books on Amazon - but as anyone who has published on Amazon would know, I have yet to see any remuneration from sales on that site (I also put the top 100 accolade down to the fact that there just aren't that many people writing political satire at present, for better or worse.) 

On a shoestring budget, we managed to do a limited print run late last year. Unfortunately I didn't take the exorbitant international NZ shipping fees into account, essentially selling out of my print run, at a loss. But you live and learn and all I really want is for people to read the books anyway.

Over the past months, Dexter's been likened to some great personalities of recent popular fiction: part 'Dustin Hoffman in Rainman', infused with the 'subtle wit of Forrest Gump' and he 'most certainly is a 21st century version of Ignatius J Reilly' from the incredible book, A Confederacy of Dunces' (my personal favourite as I loved that book growing up.)

Harry Mulisch (author of the widely acclaimed 'Discovery of Heaven') who mentored me in the beginning, told me he was 'in love with the character' before he sadly passed away in 2010.

By no means does my Dexter bear any resemblance to the character of the popular US television show of the same name - hand to heart, the name came to me before I even knew such a show existed. For that I would have to watch television in the first place.

What We Need & What We'll Create for you

These funds would help us run a second print run of the first volume ("Becoming Dexter") as well as finance targeted online campaigns to stir greater publicity and pay for the proof reading/editing of the next 3 volumes.

Eventually a dream would also be to organise a book launch and the compiling of the final Anthology  - all four volumes - as one illustrated hardback coffee table edition.

In a nutshell the four volumes are split as follows:

Vol. 1: "Becoming Dexter" (already published): This is the prologue of the story if you will. It explores Dexter's early life, his airline fiasco that results in him getting free air miles for the rest of his life and his first, tentative exposure to American culture. It is largely set in New Zealand and North America.

Vol. 2: "Being Dexter" (finished and in post-production): His adventures take him to Europe, where he encounters a barrage of unique characters and cultures, framing them in his own unique 'kiwi' way. Shedding some light on the dichotomy of people that exist on this continent. This is his true 'coming of age' book- hence the title.

Vol. 3: "Leaving Dexter" (planned): The journey continues to Asia, where Dexter faces a complete overhaul of his culinary and cultural values. He fights his first bouts with homesickness and falls in love for a third time. Without revealing too much plot line, the stage becomes set for his final and possibly most important encounter.

Vol. 4: "Dexter Returns" (in planning): After a significant event in Vol. 3, Dexter's character gets a new 'lease on life' and travels to some of the most forlorn areas on this planet, South America, Africa whilst finally traversing to the Middle East, where he attempts to have a tangible input on the Israel/Palestine conflict and impending peace conference. Oh no!? say you.. Oh yes! say we. Trust us, it will resonate on many levels.

We are also set to record an audio book of all the volumes as well as an extended videologue; where we get the author and a few of the people involved to discuss the story and read the chapters (see it as an extended dvd extras piece - sort of like a director's commentary but a lot funnier and more enlightening- we think).

Oh and the art work is a whole story in itself and shall be revealed to each contributor, secretly. But you really want a print. They are spectacular. And different. Just like the story.

The Impact

Seeing that our main character does float about on the nigh' all-encompassing, yet slightly controversial spectrum of autism, we have approached the Mental Health Foundation of New Zealand for support; whereby we will donate a percentage of any proceeds to their fantastic "Rethinking Mental Illness" campaign. I used to work with children with autism and have first hand experience of the immense work that goes into taking care of these amazing human beings. They need all the support they can get. 

The least we can do if this series turns out to be fiscally successful is to give back. That's what we are all about - as we never intended to make a lot of money with the story- it was catharsis first and foremost and it is more important to us that people read it and tell others about it, as we believe it does have the ability to break down barriers and get people talking. About the things that really matter.

Other Ways You Can Help

Naturally, most of you who see this campaign won't be able to contribute. That's a given! So what we thought we could do for you guys, is get you to send your email address to editor@cvrpress.co.nz so that we can at least send you a free eBook - as a token of our appreciation for you taking the time to read through our campaign and taking an interest in the story. If you like the story, we don't want you to link it to your network, but rather bring it up in conversation at the next dinner party you attend.

Old school-styles. 

Much love to you all and Kia ora from Aotearoa (Land of the Long White Cloud) New Zealand. 

About The Author

This is a book I have dreamed my whole life about writing. Having a character that is slightly socially awkward yet genius in his own way wander the world and document it as he sees it - both quixotically and empathetically - feels liberating. The stories fly into my head and it is easy for me to write them down as the character comes naturally to me.

Perhaps a bit of background; previously, in another life, I studied to be a biologist in the UK, trained as an immunologist in the US and after spending some years as a research scientist at hospitals and biotech companies, ended up as a medical writer. At one point in my career I found myself spending a lot of time on cancer wards here in New Zealand discussing inoperable tumours and advanced-stage cancer patients. Long story short, writing this book (especially the main character, Dexter) saved me from the debilitating bouts of depression that accompany anyone who has spent time around people with late-stage cancer and whose innate sensitivity makes it difficult to process these realities in any meaningful way.

Humour, in this case, was a means to escape the overbearing reality I was confronted with at the time. It quite literally forced me to start scribbling notes about Dexter in various situations and places, whilst waiting to talk to oncologists about patients who had little to no hope of survival beyond a few months. My own life line to say the least. A way to capture the stoic, inescapable reality of life, with a bit of humour.

For all you lucky contributors getting poems and spoken word art perks, here a not-at-all-pretentious little video showcasing my lyrical vernacular. Enjoy!

http://vimeo.com/34351685

story:
For 8 months now, The Peace factory has changed the mind of tens thousands of people in the Middle East. For 8 months now Israelis and Iranians people are saying to each other : "We love you, we don't want war between us". They started to talk to each other like they never could before. Thanks to a first campaign on Indiegogo, 70 buses in Tel Aviv were advertising Peace with ours posters during 3 weeks and showed to Israel, Iran and the rest of the world that people of the Middle East are ready for Peace.

 

Now elections are coming in Israel (22 january 2013) and again we hear politicians talking about the enemies of Israel, about being strong and ready for a war ...

We want to show to the Israeli people that the people of the middle east, theirs neighbors, are ready for peace.

We want to send a message to the Israeli people. To show them the real faces of the people in the Middle East, the ones we see everyday on our facebook pages : people that want peace, people that are not our ennemies !


You always wanted to contribute for Peace ? 

You always asked yourself how to help israelis, Palestinians and the region of the middle East to reach Peace ?

Here, you have the opportunity to contribute to a major change !

Help us to convince the Israelis to vote NOT out of fear, NOT out of hate, but to vote FOR PEACE. Dont let them be victims of political propaganda.

Thanks to your contributions, together, we can advertise for peace !

Peace is the key of most of our problems. It is up to us, the new generation in Israel and the Middle East to break the circle, to prove that there is another path, a better future : Peace.

It is time we step forward ! It is time to vote for peace.

Help us to make it happen !

What do we need this money for ?

We will launch a mass media campaign all over Israel in December and January, showing the faces of people from the Middle East (Palestinians, Iranians, Syrians, Turkish, Egyptians....) saying to the Israeli people :" we love you, we want peace with you " - VOTE FOR PEACE !

With the money we will be able to buy advertising spaces on street furnitures (bus stations) and billboards in every major city in Israel

Everybody in Israel will see our posters advertising for peace, just like they will see the messages of the political parties advertsing war,

Of course the money will also help to keep our team working on this goal, like they did for 8 months, everyday, all day long.
